69DISC004SnakeAcornsoft, BBC SoftS/Snake-69.ssdRMazeBlockade, Snake1982Fun Games11V5YY0<p>Snake is a clone of the 1976 arcade game&nbsp;<a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5v-0CwiabZA">Blockade</a> from Gremlin.</p> <p>Blockade is believed to have been the original 'Snake' game, although the 1982 arcade game <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YTFOwqZcEP4">Nibbler</a> from Rock-Ola, may be the first where the snake grows after eating food.</p>

556DISC031Starquake (AKA Star Quake)Bubble Bus, 8-Bit Software (8 Bit Software) (8BS)S/Starquake-556.ssdRPlatform PuzzlerArcade Adventure1987Kenton PriceO11NY0<p>This game gives you a password on completing a level. This can be used to skip to the next level the next time the game is played. These may be listed as an easter egg somewhere in the instructions screens. Try pressing P.</p> <p>Later published on the 8BS Public Domain disc TBI-139</p>
557DISC031UridiumHewson ConsultantsU/Uridium-557.ssdRSpace Shooter (Scrolling)1987Angus HughesO11NY0<p>This game doesn't seem to work very well in jsbeeb. In BBC mode it doesn't work at all, and in master mode it seems stuck in demo mode. Bugs have been raised to document this, jsbeeb issue <a href="https://github.com/mattgodbolt/jsbeeb/issues/130">130</a> <a href="https://github.com/mattgodbolt/jsbeeb/issues/140">140</a> and <a href="https://github.com/mattgodbolt/jsbeeb/issues/152">152</a>. See also a <a href="http://www.stardot.org.uk/forums/viewtopic.php?f=51&amp;t=11165&amp;p=150080&amp;hilit=uridium#p150166">discussion in the stardot forum</a>, and <a href="http://stardot.org.uk/forums/viewtopic.php?f=51&amp;t=13967#p184559">another one here</a>. The play button has been enabled to play it in BBC Master mode, which seems to work best, but it is probably best to download the disc image and play it in an emulator.</p>

76025DISC043Chuckie Egg 4 (AKA Chukee Egg 4) [hack]Self-publishedC/ChuckieEgg4-760.ssdLPlatformer1984Doug Anderson, Anon14Unofficial releaseNY0<p>Extra levels for the classic <a href="game.php?id=25">Chuckie Egg</a>.&nbsp;</p> <p>According to the <a href="http://web.archive.org/web/20060211065752/http://www.bagshot-row.org:80/chuckie-egg/hacksandupgrades.html">Hacks and Upgrades</a> section of the now-defunct website <a href="http://web.archive.org/web/20050918052628/http://www.bagshot-row.org/chuckie-egg/">The Chuckie Egg Professional's Resource Kit</a>, "This is a straight-forward, anonymous modification of the original BBC 32K Chuckie Egg release with some modified levels based originally on the eight levels supplied with <a href="game.php?id=509">CHUKEE</a> from BIT TWIDDLERS".</p>

836DISC047HunchBackPersonal Computer World (PCW) (VNU Publications), Personal Computer Games (PCG) (VNU Publications), Electron User Group, Century Communications Ltd.H/HunchBack-836.ssdMPlatformerHunchback1984Barry WakelinPCW Games Collection (BOOK)11NY0<p>Published in Issue 10 of Personal Computer Games, September 1984.</p> <p>Published on the <a href="index.php?rt_R=&amp;rt_B=&amp;rt_M=&amp;rt_P=&amp;rt_U=&amp;rt_W=&amp;rt_L=&amp;search=pcw+games+collection&amp;on_T=on&amp;on_Y=on&amp;on_P=on&amp;on_A=on&amp;on_G=on&amp;on_S=on&amp;on_Z=on&amp;on_C=on&amp;sort=a">PCW Games Collection</a> from Personal Computer World magazine.</p> <p>These compilation cassettes were published by Century Communications Ltd.</p> <p>Later published on the Electron User Group PD Disc 38 in June 1998.</p> <p>The PCW book accompanying the <em>PCW Games Collection</em> contained the following description:</p> <blockquote> <p>Hunchback is to be found in most arcades and it is one of the more unusual games. You control Quazimodo, champion bell ringer of all France, as he scurries across the roof of the abbey to rescue his true love, Esmerelda.</p> <p>To complete each screen, pull on the bell rope and exit the screen to the right. Here is a table of what happens on each level of the game.</p> <ol> <li>Arrows and rocks fly across the screen and spears are thrown upwards.</li> <li>Same as level one plus a block appears in the middle of the screen over Quazimodo's head.</li> <li>Same as level two except that another block appears on the screen and boiling oil falls instead of spears being thrown.</li> <li>Same as level three except that another block appears on the right and both oil and spears have to be avoided.</li> <li>Similar to level four except that the two left-most blocks now become wider.</li> <li>The same as level five except that there is a rope that also must pulled to finish this screen and release Esmerelda.</li> </ol> <p>When you complete all this, Esmerelda begs poor Quazimodo to rescue her sister from a similar predicament So, being a love-struck fool, Quazi goes through it all again. This time, however, the time bonus (bottom right of the screen) decreases faster. If it reaches zero then Quazi bites the dust!</p> <p>Though this version of Hunchback may not offer all the varied levels of the arcade original, it still offers a satisfactory challenge for even the most skilled players.</p> <p>This program is also an excellent demonstration of just how BBC BASIC can be. On most other computers this game in would be unbearably slow!</p> </blockquote>

857DISC048Missile DefenderPersonal Computer World (PCW) (VNU Publications), Century Communications Ltd.M/MissileDefender-857.ssdMSpace Shooter (Gallery)Missile Command1984S. RodenPCW Games Collection (BOOK)11NYY<p>Published in the April 1984 issue of Personal Computer World magazine (PCW).</p> <p>Published on the <a href="index.php?rt_R=&amp;rt_B=&amp;rt_M=&amp;rt_P=&amp;rt_U=&amp;rt_W=&amp;rt_L=&amp;search=pcw+games+collection&amp;on_T=on&amp;on_Y=on&amp;on_P=on&amp;on_A=on&amp;on_G=on&amp;on_S=on&amp;on_Z=on&amp;on_C=on&amp;sort=a">PCW Games Collection</a> from Personal Computer World magazine.</p> <p>These compilation cassettes were published by Century Communications Ltd.</p> <p>The PCW book accompanying the <em>PCW Games Collection</em> contained the following description:</p> <blockquote> <p>*** MESSAGE TO SECTOR A37 STOP ENEMY NUCLEAR MISSILES HEADING YOUR WAY STOP BEST OF LUCK STOP ***</p> <p>Just your luck to be in command when the enemy decides to take some pot shots at your sector! Missile Defender is a version of the classic arcade favourite Missile Command.</p> <p>The object of the game is to protect your cities from an onslaught of IBMs (Intercontinental Ballistic Missiles, dummy, not computers from America!) The arcade original gave you three different bases from which to launch you missiles but, due to defence budget cuts, you have just one!</p> <p>You score 25 points for each missile zapped. Every 1000 points you score gives you a new sector of four cities to protect. Each incoming missile is capable of wiping out a city and when all the cities are destroyed, the game is over. Your controls are:</p> <p style="padding-left: 30px;">Z = Left<br />X = Right<br />* = Up<br />? = Down</p> <p>Happy blasting!</p> </blockquote>
858DISC048Purple TurtlesComputer & Video Games (C&VG) (EMAP National Publications Ltd.)P/PurpleTurtles-858.ssdMPlatformer1985David Dobby11NYPublished In the February 1985 issue of Computer & Video Games. Issue 40, in the "Book Of Games" supplement.

861DISC048Repton InfinitySuperior SoftwareR/ReptonInfinity-861.ssdRMaze (Scrolling)Boulder Dash1988David Lawrence, David ActonRepton 7111770 DFS RequiredEditNY<p>The original game came with an editor so the user could create their own levels. The editor has been removed from this version to save space.</p><p>Beebem Problems with DFS 1.20</p>

959DISC054Flappa CatchaPersonal Computer World (PCW) (VNU Publications), Century Communications Ltd.F/FlappaCatcha-959.ssdBCatch 'em1984Alan RowleyPCW Games Collection (BOOK)11NY0<p>Published on the <a href="index.php?rt_R=&amp;rt_B=&amp;rt_M=&amp;rt_P=&amp;rt_U=&amp;rt_W=&amp;rt_L=&amp;search=pcw+games+collection&amp;on_T=on&amp;on_Y=on&amp;on_P=on&amp;on_A=on&amp;on_G=on&amp;on_S=on&amp;on_Z=on&amp;on_C=on&amp;sort=a">PCW Games Collection</a> from Personal Computer World magazine.</p> <p>These compilation cassettes were published by Century Communications Ltd.</p> <p>The PCW book accompanying the <em>PCW Games Collection</em> contained the following description:</p> <blockquote> <p>You are Sam. Together with your girlfriend, Ethel, you have been trying to steal the ill-qotten gold of an evil old witch, mad Mabel. You've both been nabbed by Mabel and Ethel is held in a cage ready for supper - Mabel's!</p> <p>To provide sport to help her appetite, Mabel has trapped you between two walls and is launching exploding demon-birds at you. You do, however, have a hat with magical properties which will neutralize the birds if you can catch them in it before they land.</p> <p>For every six birds caught Mabel will give you a bag of gold. You need three bags to win the game and save Ethel.</p> <p>Every time you miss a bird, Mabel's pet zombie will gradually tunnel under a wall and eventually get you! If you are hit by a bird you will be instantly vaporized. You have only three lives! Be careful, because if Mabel thinks you're doing too well you'll have to dodge a few lightning bolts as well!</p> <p>Your controls for moving about to catch the birds are:</p> <p style="padding-left: 30px;">Z = Left<br />X = Riqht</p> </blockquote>

986DISC055OmniopolyPersonal Computer World (PCW) (VNU Publications), Century Communications Ltd., Electron User GroupO/Omniopoly-986.ssdMBoard Game (Monopoly)Monopoly1984Richard SmithPCW Games Collection (BOOK)22V1.40NY0<p>Published in the January and March 1984 issues of Personal Computer World magazine (PCW).</p> <p>Published on the <a href="index.php?rt_R=&amp;rt_B=&amp;rt_M=&amp;rt_P=&amp;rt_U=&amp;rt_W=&amp;rt_L=&amp;search=pcw+games+collection&amp;on_T=on&amp;on_Y=on&amp;on_P=on&amp;on_A=on&amp;on_G=on&amp;on_S=on&amp;on_Z=on&amp;on_C=on&amp;sort=a">PCW Games Collection</a> from Personal Computer World magazine.</p> <p>These compilation cassettes were published by Century Communications Ltd.</p> <p>Later published on the Electron User Group PD Disc 54 in October 2000.</p> <p>The PCW book accompanying the <em>PCW Games Collection</em> contained the following description:</p> <blockquote> <p>Omniopoly bears more than a passing resemblance to a well-known board game... become a property millionaire! The computer plays the Bank and displays a very realistic board, while two human opponents compete against each other. The only change to the standard rules is the Auction Rule. In the board game a property is auctioned if not purchased by the first player to land on it, but this does not apply with the computer version. All other features of the board game are supported, and presentation of this excellent game rivals that of commercial versions. See you in Mayfair!</p> </blockquote>

999DISC056Martian AttackPersonal Computer World (PCW) (VNU Publications), Century Communications Ltd.M/MartianAttack-999.ssdBSpace Shooter (Gallery)1984Adam Ruddle, James Byrne, Nikola StojanovicPCW Games Collection (BOOK)11NY0<p>Originally authored by Nikola Stojanovic and converted to the BBC Micro by Adam Ruddle and James Byrne.</p> <p>Published on the <a href="index.php?rt_R=&amp;rt_B=&amp;rt_M=&amp;rt_P=&amp;rt_U=&amp;rt_W=&amp;rt_L=&amp;search=pcw+games+collection&amp;on_T=on&amp;on_Y=on&amp;on_P=on&amp;on_A=on&amp;on_G=on&amp;on_S=on&amp;on_Z=on&amp;on_C=on&amp;sort=a">PCW Games Collection</a> from Personal Computer World magazine.</p> <p>These compilation cassettes were published by Century Communications Ltd.</p> <p>The PCW book accompanying the <em>PCW Games Collection</em> contained the following description:</p> <blockquote> <p>Martian Attack is an arcade style game for a 32K BBC Micro, once again the earth is under attack from strange Martian creatures!</p> <p>Your task is to defeat the irksome invaders and save the earth. To aid your mission you have a helicopter and a plane under control. The plane is used to shoot down the alien spacecraft while the helicopter attempts to reach the landing pad at the top of the screen. When you reach the platform you pass on to the next level of the game.</p> <p>As the helicopter nears the platform the aliens change from modules into heads, and the number of points scored for zapping them increases. At each successive level, the number of aliens increases, making it more and more difficult to complete the level.</p> <p>A point to note when typing in this program is that a lot of the variables are in lower case letters and should be typed in as such. Be careful not to confuse them with capitals or the program may not work properly.</p> </blockquote>

1012DISC057City SmasherPersonal Computer World (PCW) (VNU Publications), Personal Computer Games (PCG) (VNU Publications), Century Communications Ltd.C/CitySmasher-1012.ssdMShooter (Gallery)1984N. BellPCW Games Collection (BOOK)11NY0<p>Published in Issue 7 of Personal Computer Games, June 1984.</p> <p>Published on the <a href="index.php?rt_R=&amp;rt_B=&amp;rt_M=&amp;rt_P=&amp;rt_U=&amp;rt_W=&amp;rt_L=&amp;search=pcw+games+collection&amp;on_T=on&amp;on_Y=on&amp;on_P=on&amp;on_A=on&amp;on_G=on&amp;on_S=on&amp;on_Z=on&amp;on_C=on&amp;sort=a">PCW Games Collection</a> from Personal Computer World magazine.</p> <p>These compilation cassettes were published by Century Communications Ltd.</p> <p>The PCW book accompanying the <em>PCW Games Collection</em> contained the following description:</p> <blockquote> <p>This is a shoot and bomb game where you are flying an aircraft over an enemy city. The plan is to hit the skyscrapers with your bombs, but these are tall tower blocks so you are also in danger of bashing into them as your plane slowly loses height during the game.</p> <p>You can move the plane down to get closer for better bombing aim and you have a laser gun mounted at the front of the plane for forward firing, in case you get too low and have to blast the top off a building to avoid it. Unfortunately this will only fire four times before it runs out of laser power. Your controls<br />are:</p> <p style="padding-left: 30px;">SPACE = Drop bombs<br />Z = Move down<br />A = Fire laser</p> </blockquote>

1053DISC059Four In A LinePersonal Computer World (PCW) (VNU Publications), Century Communications Ltd.F/FourInALine-1053.ssdBTraditional GamesConnect 41984James ByrnePCW Games Collection (BOOK)22NY0<p>Published on the <a href="index.php?rt_R=&amp;rt_B=&amp;rt_M=&amp;rt_P=&amp;rt_U=&amp;rt_W=&amp;rt_L=&amp;search=pcw+games+collection&amp;on_T=on&amp;on_Y=on&amp;on_P=on&amp;on_A=on&amp;on_G=on&amp;on_S=on&amp;on_Z=on&amp;on_C=on&amp;sort=a">PCW Games Collection</a> from Personal Computer World magazine.</p> <p>These compilation cassettes were published by Century Communications Ltd.</p> <p>The PCW book accompanying the <em>PCW Games Collection</em> contained the following description:</p> <blockquote> <p>This is a game for two players where the aim is to drop counters into a grid. The winner is the first one to get... you guessed it, four in a row.</p> <p>So, this is a game of strategy and forethought, where you have to attempt to block your opponent's moves as well as plan ahead for your own.</p> <p>In order to drop a counter you simply type the number of the column in which you wish it to go.</p> <p>Although very simple, the graphics are extremely effective and give an impression of smooth movement as the counters fall into the grid.</p> </blockquote>

1063DISC060Baby Monty (Monty Mole's Little Brother)Personal Computer World (PCW) (VNU Publications), Century Communications Ltd.B/BabyMonty-1063.ssdBPlatformer1984James Byrne, Anthony CrowtherPCW Games Collection (BOOK)11NY0<p>Originally authored by Anthony Crowther for the Commodore 64, and adapted for the BBC Micro by James Byrne.</p> <p>The original Commodore 64 listing was published in Personal Computer Games magazine, issue 9 in August 1984.</p> <p>Published on the <a href="index.php?rt_R=&amp;rt_B=&amp;rt_M=&amp;rt_P=&amp;rt_U=&amp;rt_W=&amp;rt_L=&amp;search=pcw+games+collection&amp;on_T=on&amp;on_Y=on&amp;on_P=on&amp;on_A=on&amp;on_G=on&amp;on_S=on&amp;on_Z=on&amp;on_C=on&amp;sort=a">PCW Games Collection</a> from Personal Computer World magazine.</p> <p>These compilation cassettes were published by Century Communications Ltd.</p> <p>The PCW book accompanying the <em>PCW Games Collection</em> contained the following description:</p> <blockquote> <p>Monty the mole's baby brother is trapped in a series of deep, dark underground caverns which are slowly filling with water. Luckily he has found an old boat and is rowing like mad - he has to, to avoid the barrels which are mysteriously tumbling down on top of him.</p> <p>The walls are also a source of danger, as they will sink the boat if it bumps into them. He will also be crushed to death if trapped try the rising tide against the ceiling of the caves. However, you can help the miserable mole by steering the boat safely through the maze of caves. Strangely enough you can also use the flood to float the boat to the surface at the top of the screen faster. Your controls for this subterranean mission are:</p> <p style="padding-left: 30px;">Z = Left<br />X = Right<br />SHIFT = Raise water level</p> <p>Can you save the mole from a watery grave and get him back to his mummy?</p> </blockquote>

1112DISC062Race ChasePersonal Computer World (PCW) (VNU Publications), Century Communications Ltd., Electron User GroupR/RaceChase-1112.ssdBDriving (Maze)Head On1983D. Denholm, Paul BorrettBest Of PCW Software For The BBC Micro (BOOK)11NY0<p>Originally authored by D. Denholm, and converted for the BBC Micro by Paul Borrett.</p> <p>Published on the <a href="index.php?rt_R=&amp;rt_B=&amp;rt_M=&amp;rt_P=&amp;rt_U=&amp;rt_W=&amp;rt_L=&amp;search=best+of+PCW+software&amp;on_T=on&amp;on_Y=on&amp;on_P=on&amp;on_A=on&amp;on_G=on&amp;on_S=on&amp;on_Z=on&amp;on_C=on&amp;sort=a">Best of PCW software for the BBC Micro</a> compilation from Personal Computer World magazine.</p> <p>These compilation cassettes were published by Century Communications Ltd.</p> <p>Later published on the Electron User Group PD Disc 51 in June 2000.</p> <p>The PCW book accompanying the <em>Best of PCW Software For The BBC Micro</em> cassette contained the following description:</p> <blockquote> <p>This challenging game is based on a car race. You pilot a car round a five-lane track, trying to hit as many dots as possible. However, to hinder you a mad driver is travelling in the opposite direction trying to crash his car into yours!</p> <p>Try and cover as many dots as you can before he hits you. Controls are by two keys: Z to move in a lane, and M to move out a lane, and you are in the car travelling anti-clockwise.</p> <p>If you manage to eradicate all the dots successfully a new track will appear.</p> </blockquote>

Roe, and converted for the BBC Micro by Brian Jones.</p> <p>Published on the <a href="index.php?rt_R=&amp;rt_B=&amp;rt_M=&amp;rt_P=&amp;rt_U=&amp;rt_W=&amp;rt_L=&amp;search=best+of+PCW+software&amp;on_T=on&amp;on_Y=on&amp;on_P=on&amp;on_A=on&amp;on_G=on&amp;on_S=on&amp;on_Z=on&amp;on_C=on&amp;sort=a">Best of PCW software for the BBC Micro</a> compilation from Personal Computer World magazine.</p> <p>These compilation cassettes were published by Century Communications Ltd.</p> <p>Later published on the Electron User Group PD Disc 47 in January 2000.</p> <p>The PCW book accompanying the <em>Best of PCW Software For The BBC Micro</em> cassette contained the following description:</p> <blockquote> <p>In this exciting game you must steer a balloon through a rocky ravine to safety. You control your balloon with the keys shown in the introduction sequence and you must avoid having the rocks burst your balloon. Easy, except that your balloon says from side to side in the wind and can easily swing back at just the wrong moment. It takes a lot of patience and skill to win at this game! Bon voyage, and I hope it doesn't take you eighty days to get through this one.</p> </blockquote>

1136DISC064AdventureAcorn User (later BBC Acorn User) (Redwood Publishing Ltd.)A/Adventure-1136.ssdMAdventureGraphic Adventure1986Bob AndersonAcorn User Games Compendium11NY0This game appears to be loosely based on "Adventure" for the Atari 2600 by Warren Robinett. Released on the Acorn User games compendium tape in October 1986, this is the only game on the cassette that was not previously published as an Acorn User type-in. The compendium comprises <a href="http://bbcmicro.co.uk/game.php?id=463">Spectramania</a>, <a href="http://bbcmicro.co.uk/game.php?id=1077">Quadline</a>, <a href="http://bbcmicro.co.uk/game.php?id=1274">Picture Slide</a>, <a href="http://bbcmicro.co.uk/game.php?id=1486">Maze</a>, <a href="http://bbcmicro.co.uk/game.php?id=1693">Acorn User Office Adventure</a>, <a href="http://bbcmicro.co.uk/game.php?id=753">Shuggy's Garden</a>, <a href="http://bbcmicro.co.uk/game.php?id=391">Run Silent Run Deep</a>, and <a href="http://bbcmicro.co.uk/game.php?id=1136">Adventure</a>.

All you have to do is to guide it into your sights and fire.</p> <p>A point to note when typing in this listing is that memory is very limited and so all non-essential spaces should be removed, as they are here.</p> </blockquote>

1161DISC065Fighter PilotPersonal Computer World (PCW) (VNU Publications), Personal Computer Games (PCG) (VNU Publications), Century Communications Ltd.F/FighterPilot-1161.ssdBSimulation (Flight)Flight Simulator1983Harcharam Wassi, E.G. KemplenBest Of PCW Software For The BBC Micro (BOOK)11NY0<p>Originally authored by E.G. Kemplen, and converted for the BBC Micro by Haracham Wassi</p> <p>Published in Issue 4 of Personal Computer Games, March 1984.</p> <p>Published on the <a href="index.php?rt_R=&amp;rt_B=&amp;rt_M=&amp;rt_P=&amp;rt_U=&amp;rt_W=&amp;rt_L=&amp;search=best+of+PCW+software&amp;on_T=on&amp;on_Y=on&amp;on_P=on&amp;on_A=on&amp;on_G=on&amp;on_S=on&amp;on_Z=on&amp;on_C=on&amp;sort=a">Best of PCW software for the BBC Micro</a> compilation from Personal Computer World magazine.</p> <p>These compilation cassettes were published by Century Communications Ltd.</p> <p>The PCW book accompanying the <em>Best of PCW Software For The BBC Micro</em> cassette contained the following description:</p> <blockquote> <p>You are seated in the cockpit of your Spitfire, hot on the tail of an enemy aircraft. He, not unnaturally, is doing his level best to get out of your gun sights. The object of the game is to score 50 points by hitting the target as often as you can, before your fuel runs out.</p> <p>You can control your aircraft so as to climb, dive, swoop to the left or right, the screen display always shows the position of the enemy in your line of fire. Displays of your current score, number of shots, and fuel level are also provided. A good eye, and considerable dexterity are needed to play this game well; eleven fingers are also an advantage!</p> </blockquote>

1240DISC069Satellite Havoc II8-Bit Software (8 Bit Software) (8BS)S/SatelliteHavocII-1240.ssdPSpace Shooter (Gallery)1992A. Sattar ShakoorSatellite Havoc 211NY0Published on the 8BS Public Domain disc 21 in September 1992.
1241DISC069Search & Rescue (AKA Search And Rescue)Personal Computer World (PCW) (VNU Publications), Century Communications Ltd., Electron User GroupS/SearchRescue-1241.ssdBCollect 'Em Up1983Geoffrey Little, Michael Orton, Paul BorrettBest Of PCW Software For The BBC Micro (BOOK)11NYY<p>Originally authored by Geoffrey Little and Michael Orton, and converted for the BBC Micro by Paul Borrett.</p> <p>Published on the <a href="index.php?rt_R=&amp;rt_B=&amp;rt_M=&amp;rt_P=&amp;rt_U=&amp;rt_W=&amp;rt_L=&amp;search=best+of+PCW+software&amp;on_T=on&amp;on_Y=on&amp;on_P=on&amp;on_A=on&amp;on_G=on&amp;on_S=on&amp;on_Z=on&amp;on_C=on&amp;sort=a">Best of PCW software for the BBC Micro</a> compilation from Personal Computer World magazine.</p> <p>These compilation cassettes were published by Century Communications Ltd.</p> <p>Later published on the Electron User Group PD Disc 54 in October 2000.</p> <p>The PCW book accompanying the <em>Best of PCW Software For The BBC Micro</em> cassette contained the following description:</p> <blockquote> <p>This is an exciting game, with good graphics and sound, requiring some skill in successfully piloting a search and rescue helicopter on its rescue mission.</p> <p>By using four different keys: up = ':', down = '/', left = 'Z', and right = 'X', you move the helicopter into a position to pick up men from a ship in distress and deliver them safely to land. However, you only have a limited amount of fuel on board, so don't stray away from the land for too long and beware of crashing into the sea!</p> </blockquote>

1248DISC070GalaxianPersonal Computer Games (PCG) (VNU Publications)G/Galaxian-1248.ssdMSpace Shooter (Gallery)Galaxian1984Colin Tanner11NY0<p>Published in Issue 3 of Personal Computer Games, February 1984.</p> <p>The magazine listing states the games was "converted to 32K BBC Micro by C.R. Tanner".</p> <p>This issue of Personal Computer Games also had a free flexi-disc on the cover which contained the type-ins from the magazine.</p> <p>The question of which was easier, typing in the listing, or getting the computer to recognise the flexi-disc is a different matter!</p>
1249DISC070Holed Out!!4th Dimension, Superior SoftwareH/HoledOut-1249.ssdRSport (Golf)Cone Links, Pine Isles1989Gordon J. KeyPlay It Again Sam 18Holed Out 1142 x Banks SWR RequiredNY0<p>If you are playing this game on a real BBC micro, it requires 2 banks of "Sideways RAM" which load into banks 4 and 5.</p>
1250DISC070Hunger AlleyPersonal Computer World (PCW) (VNU Publications), Century Communications Ltd.H/HungerAlley-1250.ssdBMazeArcade, Pac-Man1984Anwar Sidat, Sadiq Norat, Soyab Norat, Adam RuddlePCW Games Collection (BOOK)11NY0<p>Originally authored by Anwar Sidat, Sadiq Norat, and Soyab Norat. Converted to the BBC Micro by Adam Ruddle.</p> <p>Published on the <a href="index.php?rt_R=&amp;rt_B=&amp;rt_M=&amp;rt_P=&amp;rt_U=&amp;rt_W=&amp;rt_L=&amp;search=pcw+games+collection&amp;on_T=on&amp;on_Y=on&amp;on_P=on&amp;on_A=on&amp;on_G=on&amp;on_S=on&amp;on_Z=on&amp;on_C=on&amp;sort=a">PCW Games Collection</a> from Personal Computer World magazine.</p> <p>These compilation cassettes were published by Century Communications Ltd.</p> <p>The PCW book accompanying the <em>PCW Games Collection</em> contained the following description:</p> <blockquote> <p>No book of games would be complete without an appearance of the king of the arcade - PAC-MAN. In this version, you have to move around a maze gobbling up food pills and avoid poisoned skulls - unless you have just eaten a power pill. After eating one of these, you flash, change colour and are allowed a time of 500 units to devour the nasty skulls. You score 10 points for each pill eaten, 30 for each power pill and 50 for each skull.</p> <p>The game has nine different coloured screens and you around by operating four different keys:</p> <p style="padding-left: 30px;">Z - Left<br />X = Right<br />* = Up<br />? = Down</p> <p>Remember, speed is the key word in this game, so gobble up those pills as fast as you can!</p> </blockquote>

1472DISC082Splash!Personal Computer World (PCW) (VNU Publications), Century Communications Ltd.S/Splash-1472.ssdMPuzzle1984Jeff AughtonPCW Games Collection (BOOK)11NY0<p>Published in the April 1984 issue of Personal Computer World magazine (PCW).</p> <p>Published on the <a href="index.php?rt_R=&amp;rt_B=&amp;rt_M=&amp;rt_P=&amp;rt_U=&amp;rt_W=&amp;rt_L=&amp;search=pcw+games+collection&amp;on_T=on&amp;on_Y=on&amp;on_P=on&amp;on_A=on&amp;on_G=on&amp;on_S=on&amp;on_Z=on&amp;on_C=on&amp;sort=a">PCW Games Collection</a> from Personal Computer World magazine.</p> <p>These compilation cassettes were published by Century Communications Ltd.</p> <p>The PCW book accompanying the <em>PCW Games Collection</em> contained the following description:</p> <blockquote> <p>This a new and different board game for two players: the computer and you. The players take turns to 'drop' their counters onto their chosen square in a 7 by 7 grid, but the 'splash' of colour onto surrounding squares may give your opponent the advantage. The effects are predictable and the computer can keep track of what will happen, but can you?</p> <p>Full instructions are contained within the program. Lines 2000-2330 contain an assembly language routine and you should be especially careful to type these lines exactly as they are shown.</p> </blockquote> <p>&nbsp;</p>
1473DISC082Superman: Man Of SteelTynesoftS/SupermanManOfSteel-1473.ssdRShooter (Gallery)1989Kevin Blake11Tape VersionNY0<p>To run the game, you have to type&nbsp;<em>CHAIN "LOADER"</em></p> <p>There were thirty-one files on the original disc, which is the limit for the standard Acorn DFS disc filing system.&nbsp;Therefore there was no room for a <em>!BOOT</em> file. So, to run the game, you have to type <em>CHAIN "LOADER"</em></p> <p>&nbsp;</p>

1503DISC084Dogfight (AKA Dog Fight)Personal Computer World (PCW) (VNU Publications), Century Communications Ltd.D/Dogfight-1503.ssdMShooter (Gallery)1984E.J. BarfieldPCW Games Collection (BOOK)22NY0<p>Published in the February 1984 issue of Personal Computer World magazine (PCW).</p> <p>Published on the <a href="index.php?rt_R=&amp;rt_B=&amp;rt_M=&amp;rt_P=&amp;rt_U=&amp;rt_W=&amp;rt_L=&amp;search=pcw+games+collection&amp;on_T=on&amp;on_Y=on&amp;on_P=on&amp;on_A=on&amp;on_G=on&amp;on_S=on&amp;on_Z=on&amp;on_C=on&amp;sort=a">PCW Games Collection</a> from Personal Computer World magazine.</p> <p>These compilation cassettes were published by Century Communications Ltd.</p> <p>The PCW book accompanying the <em>PCW Games Collection</em> contained the following description:</p> <blockquote> <p>Dogfight is an excellent 'shoot 'em up' type of game, but it is somewhat unusual because it involves two players playing against each other.</p> <p>The game is an air battle between two planes - a dogfight, in fact. The aim is to score 10 hits against your opponent before you run out of fuel. Each player has a choice of either a jet or a biplane; the jet is faster but has a larger turning circle and consumes more fuel.</p> <p>Having selected their planes the players must choose the amount ammunition they wish to take with them on their sortie; this should be a value between 10 and 99. You will also be asked if you wish to fly in a clear sky or one with clouds. Novice pilots may need the security of clouds because the opposing flyer cannot shoot down while you are hidden from view. The controls are:</p> <table style="border-collapse: collapse; width: 100%;" border="1"> <tbody> <tr style="height: 18px;"> <td style="width: 50%; height: 18px; text-align: center;">PLAYER 1 (blue)</td> <td style="width: 50%; height: 18px; text-align: center;">PLAYER 2 (black)</td> </tr> <tr style="height: 18px;"> <td style="width: 50%; height: 18px; text-align: center;">W=Left</td> <td style="width: 50%; height: 18px; text-align: center;">O=Left</td> </tr> <tr style="height: 18px;"> <td style="width: 50%; height: 18px; text-align: center;">E=Right</td> <td style="width: 50%; height: 18px; text-align: center;">P=Right</td> </tr> <tr style="height: 18px;"> <td style="width: 50%; height: 18px; text-align: center;">A=Fire</td> <td style="width: 50%; height: 18px; text-align: center;">K=Fire</td> </tr> </tbody> </table> <p>&nbsp;</p> </blockquote>

1516DISC085Black HolesModel B Computing (Argus Press Software) (APS), Electron User Group, Century Communications Ltd.B/BlackHoles-1516.ssdMPuzzleKeep colours apart1984Freda PerrowPCW Games Collection (BOOK)Model B Computing Cassette 0711NY0<p>Published on the "Model B Computing" cassette number 7 in October/November 1984.</p> <p>Published as part of the <a href="index.php?rt_R=&amp;rt_B=&amp;rt_M=&amp;rt_P=&amp;rt_U=&amp;rt_W=&amp;rt_L=&amp;search=PCW+Games+Collection&amp;sort=b">PCW Games Collection</a></p> <p>Later published on the Electron User Group PD Disc 40 in October 1998.</p> <p>The PCW book accompanying the <em>PCW Games Collection</em> contained the following description:</p> <blockquote> <p>Black Holes is not a high-speed action game, but a game of skill and strategy with a little bit of luck thrown in for good measure.</p> <p>Twenty-five aliens appear at the bottom of the screen, one at a time and in one of five colours. The colour of each is chosen at random and your task is to store these creatures in the black holes. Each black hole is identified by a letter, and you choose them by pressing the appropriate keys on the keyboard.</p> <p>The first four aliens that appear must be placed in the four corners of the grid. After that they may be placed anywhere on the screen, providing the following rules are obeyed:</p> <ol> <li>Each alien must be placed next to another one.</li> <li>Aliens of the same colour must not be placed next to each other.</li> <li>Aliens must be stored before they cross the screen, otherwise the game is lost.</li> </ol> </blockquote>
1517DISC085CheesePersonal Computer World (PCW) (VNU Publications), Century Communications Ltd.C/Cheese-1517.ssdBCatch 'em1983Paul Bradshaw, James ByrneBest Of PCW Software For The BBC Micro (BOOK)11NY0<p>Originally authored by Paul Bradshaw, and converted for the BBC Micro by James Byrne.</p> <p>Published on the <a href="index.php?rt_R=&amp;rt_B=&amp;rt_M=&amp;rt_P=&amp;rt_U=&amp;rt_W=&amp;rt_L=&amp;search=best+of+PCW+software&amp;on_T=on&amp;on_Y=on&amp;on_P=on&amp;on_A=on&amp;on_G=on&amp;on_S=on&amp;on_Z=on&amp;on_C=on&amp;sort=a">Best of PCW software for the BBC Micro</a> compilation from Personal Computer World magazine.</p> <p>These compilation cassettes were published by Century Communications Ltd.</p> <p>The accompanying book contained the following description:</p> <blockquote> <p>This is a nice simple game in which you play the role of a sly cat. Your task is to prevent mice from eating a hunk of cheese. Instructions for moving, and for trapping mice, will appear on the screen when the program is run.</p> <p>You score points for eating the mice as quickly as possible when they appear. If you don't kill them they will eventually run into the cheese and take a huge bite out of it. When all the cheese is gone the game is over. Happy mouse-hunting!</p> </blockquote>

1586DISC089Alien Blaster (AKA Blaster)Personal Computer World (PCW) (VNU Publications), Electron User Group, Century Communications Ltd.A/AlienBlaster-1586.ssdBSpace Shooter (Gallery)1983Alan Green, Daniel LucasBest Of PCW Software For The BBC Micro (BOOK)11NY0<p>Originally authored for the Sinclair Spectrum by Alan Green, then converted for the BBC Micro by Daniel Lucas.</p> <p>The original Spectrum listing was published in issue 1 (Summer 1983) of Personal Computer Games magazine from VNU publishing.</p> <p>Published on the <a href="index.php?rt_R=&amp;rt_B=&amp;rt_M=&amp;rt_P=&amp;rt_U=&amp;rt_W=&amp;rt_L=&amp;search=best+of+PCW+software&amp;on_T=on&amp;on_Y=on&amp;on_P=on&amp;on_A=on&amp;on_G=on&amp;on_S=on&amp;on_Z=on&amp;on_C=on&amp;sort=a">Best of PCW software for the BBC Micro</a> compilation from Personal Computer World magazine.</p> <p>These compilation cassettes were published by Century Communications Ltd.</p> <p>Later published on the Electron User Group PD Disc 40 in October 1998.</p> <p>The book accompanying the <em>Best of PCW Software for the BBC</em> compilation contained the following description:</p> <blockquote> <p>This is a simple but addictive game that uses sound and colour to good effect.</p> <p>Menacing Aliens are trying to colonise the earth and to save us all you must shoot them down before they land. Inexorably, the nearer they get the higher they score, and you have got to act very fast - only five have to land to take over the planet!</p> </blockquote>

1666DISC093RunestaffSquaresoftR/Runestaff-1666.ssdMAdventureText, Text Adventure1987Martyn AmosSTD11YesNY0<p>Written with <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Quill_(software)">The Quill</a>, this game won the Electron User competition for the best home-written adventure game in the December 1987 issue (volume 5, number 3).</p> <p>Martyn <a href="https://www.facebook.com/groups/EightBitAdventures/permalink/2286893454674012/?comment_id=2286942428002448&amp;reply_comment_id=2286946661335358&amp;comment_tracking=%7B%22tn%22%3A%22R6%22%7D">says</a> that he came up with the name "Squaresoft" because he was one of the squares at school!</p> <p>&nbsp;</p>

184025DISC103Chuckie Egg 2009 [game only] (AKA Chuckie Egg 6) [hack]Organ Grinder's MonkeyC/ChuckieEgg2009gameonly-1840.ssdLPlatformer2009Dave Edwards (The Dave), Doug Anderson14YesUnofficial releaseNY0<p>Eight&nbsp;extra levels by Dave Edwards for the classic <a href="game.php?id=25">Chuckie Egg</a>. The levels were created with Dave Edwards's level-editor, which was part of <a href="game.php?id=2952">the original Chuckie Egg 2009 release</a>.</p> <p>The full game, including the level-editor, was published on the 8BS public-domain disc TBI-185.</p> <p>The new levels (<em>without</em> the editor) were published on the Electron User Group PD Disc 70 in 2009, and this BBC Micro game is an adaptation of that Electron release.</p>

1887DISC105TrankPersonal Computer World (PCW) (VNU Publications), Century Communications Ltd.T/Trank-1887.ssdBShooter (Gallery)Terrible1984Bill WalkerOPCW Games Collection (BOOK)11NY0<p>Published on the <a href="index.php?rt_R=&amp;rt_B=&amp;rt_M=&amp;rt_P=&amp;rt_U=&amp;rt_W=&amp;rt_L=&amp;search=pcw+games+collection&amp;on_T=on&amp;on_Y=on&amp;on_P=on&amp;on_A=on&amp;on_G=on&amp;on_S=on&amp;on_Z=on&amp;on_C=on&amp;sort=a">PCW Games Collection</a> from Personal Computer World magazine.</p> <p>These compilation cassettes were published by Century Communications Ltd.</p> <p>The PCW book accompanying the <em>PCW Games Collection</em> contained the following description:</p> <blockquote> <p>Trank is an original zapping game involving Herman, the triangular tank, and a wandering gaily coloured target. The aim is to shoot as many targets as possible, without running into them, the walls or the obstacles. Herman can be controlled by either the keyboard or two joysticks, and the method of control is a little different to most games. If you are using joysticks the left stick controls his left caterpillar track and the fight stick controls his fight caterpillar track, so if both sticks are fully forward he will go forward at top speed, and if they are both back he will go in reverse at top speed. If one stick is forward and one back he will turn. Using the keyboard is similar:</p> <p style="padding-left: 30px;">A - Left track forward<br />Z - Left track backwards<br />* - Right track forward<br />? - Right track backwards<br />SPACE - Fire</p> </blockquote>
1888DISC105WeeniesCronosoftW/Weenies-1888.ssdRPlatform PuzzlerLemmings2003Chris Dewhurst11NYThis game gives you a password on completing a level. This can be used to skip to the next level the next time the game is played. These may be listed as an easter egg somewhere in the instructions screens. Try pressing P.

1925DISC107UltimaMicro User, The (later Acorn Computing) (Database Publications)U/Ultima-1925.ssdMBoard GameChess Variant1990Terry Blunt22NY0<p>Published in Micro User Magazine vol.8 issue 5 in July 1990</p> <p>Another version of this game had already been published in Personal Software magazine, Spring 1983 edition.</p> <p>This variation on Chess was invented in 1962 by Robert Abbott. It was originally called <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Baroque_chess">Baroque Chess</a>, but was changed to Ultima at the suggestion of his publisher.</p> <p>Some variations to the rules exist.</p>

1979DISC112ArtemidorusOrchiewall SoftwareA/Artemidorus-1979.ssdWMazeCrystal Castles198611New ScreensNYIn common with most of the games on this website, the game was restored by Mick Brown. While he was able to aquire the program, he was not able to find the data files which make up the levels. Undaunted, Mick created some new levels so the game can be played again. Read the story on the <a href="http://stardot.org.uk/forums/viewtopic.php?f=6&t=9891&p=118458">stardot forums</a>. If you have access to the original data files, please <a href="http://stardot.org.uk/forums/viewtopic.php?f=6&t=11274&p=139922">let us know in the stardot forums</a>.
1980DISC111BlockadeDavid McKeranB/Blockade-1980.ssdRMazeTron, Light Cycles1983David McKeranUnoriginal Games22NY
1981DISC111Championship BoxingElectron User Group, Pan Books Ltd., Personal Computer News (PCN) (VNU Publications)C/ChampionshipBoxing-1981.ssdBSport (Boxing)1983Ian Thomas, Paul StanleySixty programs for the BBC Micro (BOOK)11NY0<p>Published in the book <em>Sixty Programs for the BBC Micro</em> by <em>Pan Books Ltd.</em> In association with <em>Personal Computer News</em>.</p> <p>Original program by Paul Stanley, converted for the BBC Micro by Ian Thomas.</p> <p>Later published on the Electron User Group PD Disc 54 in October 2000.</p> <p>Sixty Programs for the BBC Micro contains the following description:</p> <blockquote> <p>Although we say it ourselves, this program is very close to being a masterpiece. Let's face it, you're never going to make it into the ring, but the hours you spend keying-in programs amount to a great deal; of repressed aggression. So here's your chance to take on the boxing champions of the world without stirring from your armchair. The program offers you a bird's eye view of a boxing ring and the opportunity to go three rounds with an opponent of your choice. You only score points if you manage to connect with the head, and a KO is possible if your strategy's slick enough.</p> </blockquote>

2050DISC999Castle Of FearMicro User, The (later Acorn Computing) (Database Publications)C/CastleOfFear-2050.ssdMAdventureText, Text Adventure1984Marcus Adams, Michal Noels11NY0<p><em>...this isn't really an adventure. It's basically a 3D noughts and crosses (or tic-tac-toe for our American friends) that plays like a role-playing game with single-letter input played in real-time with lots of sudden-death scenarios and random events that you've got no control over. Avoid it unless you're extremely patient and prepared to play it dozens of times, even if you know the solution.</em> &mdash;Garry at <a href="http://www.solutionarchive.com/phpBB3/viewtopic.php?f=3&amp;t=981&amp;p=9003#p8997">CASA</a></p> <p>Published in Micro User magazine, volume 2, issue 6, in August 1984.</p>

2054DISC117Cells And SerpentsArgus Press Software (APS) (ASP), 8-Bit Software (8 Bit Software) (8BS), BBC PD, A&B Computing (Argus Specialist Publications Ltd.) (ASP), Computing Today (Argus Specialist Publications Ltd.) (ASP)C/CellsAndSerpents-2054.ssdRRPGText, Text Adventure1983Ian Nicholls, G. LovellSTT11YY0<p>The BBC micro game is a conversion of "Cells And Serpents", written for the NASCOM computer by G. Lovell, first published in the December 1980 issue of Computing Today magazine.</p> <p>The original, commercial BBC micro release by ASP software was in early 1983. A functionally identical, but much better annotated listing was published in the May/June 1983 issue of A&amp;B Computing (volume 1, issue 1) which credits I.G. Nicholls with the translation.<br />Later, a slightly different listing was published both on the 8BS Public Domain disc 05 in September 1990, and BBC PD Disc 10.<br />An improved version of this listing was published on both BBC PD Disc 166 (which featured Mad Rabbit PD Disc 024) and 8BS Public Domain disc 08 in January 1991 which credits the improvements to Roger Pashby in October 1990.</p>

2065DISC999CrosswordsHighlight SoftwareC/Crosswords-2065.ssdRCrossword198611NY
2066DISC999TheCrypt Of GabonAddison-Wesley Publications (Addison Wesley), Interface PublicationsC/CryptOfGabon-2066.ssdBAdventureText, Text Adventure1983Ian WattGames BBC Computers Play (BOOK)11NY0<p>From the book <em>Games BBC Computers Play</em> by Tim Hartnell, S.M. Gee, and Mike James. Published by Interface Publications.</p> <p>The introductory text reads:</p> <blockquote> <p>In this ADVENTURE program, written by Ian Watt, you start outside the crypt.</p> <p>A stolen diamond must be replaced in it's correct position within the crypt, before you make good your escape. The crypt, needless to say, is guarded by a monster which will destroy the world if the diamond is not replaced. The ambition of monster's know no bounds. You have a limited time before you will be killed by the monster, which was designed by Gabon, who is buried in the crypt.</p> <p>You have to direct the computer to manipulate the objects you come across, and to move around. As with all good ADVENTURE programs, much of the pleasure in playing comes from discovering the vocabulary the computer will understand, so we will not give too much away in the introduction. The computer has, however, an extensive vocabulary, so if one command doesn't work, try another.</p> <p>The program has been written so that only the first three letters of each command and object need to be typed in, although the computer will also accept the full word. For example, if you wished to say GET DIAMOND, the BBC Micro will accept GET DIA or GET DIAMOND. Other examples: DROP REVOLVER &ndash; DRO REV; THROW ROPE &ndash; THR ROP.</p> <p>Good luck in your quest.</p> </blockquote>
2067DISC999TheCube Of ZothDisk User, The (Argus Specialist Publications Ltd.) (ASP), A&B Computing (Argus Specialist Publications Ltd.) (ASP), 8-Bit Software (8 Bit Software) (8BS)C/CubeOfZoth-2067.ssdMAdventureText, Text Adventure1987Jane Evans, Jonathan EvansSTD11NY0<p>Published on the June/July 1987 issue of Disk User. Issue 01. <br />Written with A&amp;B Computing's "Adventurescape" system. <br />Prizes of a copy of Adventurescape were given to the first thirty readers to solve the game.</p> <p>The disc was later offered for sale in A&amp;B Computing.</p> <p>Later published on the 8BS Public Domain disc TBI-93</p>

2117DISC999TheGolden FleecePersonal Computer World (PCW) (VNU Publications), Century Communications Ltd.G/GoldenFleece-2117.ssdBAdventureText, Text Adventure, Graphics1984Simon BryanPCW Games Collection (BOOK)11NY0<p>Published on the <a href="index.php?rt_R=&amp;rt_B=&amp;rt_M=&amp;rt_P=&amp;rt_U=&amp;rt_W=&amp;rt_L=&amp;search=pcw+games+collection&amp;on_T=on&amp;on_Y=on&amp;on_P=on&amp;on_A=on&amp;on_G=on&amp;on_S=on&amp;on_Z=on&amp;on_C=on&amp;sort=a">PCW Games Collection</a> from Personal Computer World magazine.</p> <p>These compilation cassettes were published by Century Communications Ltd.</p> <p>The PCW book accompanying the <em>PCW Games Collection</em> contained the following description:</p> <blockquote> <p>Golden Fleece is an interesting adventure game with the added bonus of exciting graphics at each location. The object of your quest is to find the Golden Fleece, which is at one of the 18 locations. You may type in one or two word commands: the commands that the program understands are GO, DIG, GET, DROP, PAY, TAKE, CUT, ROW, KILL, LIGHT, OPEN and INV (inventory - to give you a list of the objects that you are carrying). Directions may be entered in any of three different ways; for example to go north you can type GO NORTH, NORTH or just N.</p> <p>The which the program is written makes it easy to extend. Each verb is dealt with by its own procedure, so to add an extra verb all you have to do is add a line to check for it, at line 535 for example, and then add a procedure to deal with it.</p> </blockquote> <p>&nbsp;</p>

(ASP)M/MysteriousYeti-2170.ssdRAdventureText, Text Adventure1986Ben CraigSTDAdventure Crazy collection no.211NY0<p>This game was not listed in the magazine. It was first advertised in the March 1986 issue of A&amp;B Computing. It was also sold on&nbsp;<a href="index.php?search=Adventure+Crazy+collection+no.2&amp;on_C=on&amp;sort=a">Adventure Crazy No.2</a>, a collection of games which comprised&nbsp;Death In Poglovia, Puss In Boots, Secret Agent, The Orb, Mysterious Yeti, and Diamond Adventure.</p>
2171DISC999TheMystery Of Silver MountainUsborne Publishing Ltd., Electron User GroupM/MysteryOfSilverMountain-2171.ssdBAdventureText, Text Adventure1984Chris Oxlade, Judy TatchellSTTThe Mystery of Silver Mountain (BOOK)11NY0<p>The Mystery Of Silver Mountain can be found as a type-in listing in the book of the same name, a free PDF of which is available to download from <a href="https://usborne.com/browse-books/features/computer-and-coding-books/">Usborne Publishing</a> (scroll to near the bottom of the page).</p> <p>As well as the listing, the book contains an illustrated background story to the adventure. Some of the illustrations contain information that may aid the adventurer.</p> <p>Later published on the Electron User Group PD Disc 59 in July 2001.</p>

2191DISC118Planetfall (AKA Planet Fall)Argus Press Software (APS) (ASP)P/Planetfall-2191.ssdRRPGTrading1983Tim Garden, Ian NichollsSTT212NY0<p>This game was originally written for the Sharp MZ-80K computer by Tim Garden.</p> <p>It was translated for the BBC micro by Ian Nicholls.</p> <p>The listings for both the Sharp and the BBC micro were printed in the August 1983 issue of Computing Today magazine.</p> <p>The game was released commercially for the BBC Micro by ASP software, but I am unsure whether this was before or after the listings were printed in the magazine.</p>

2256DISC118TheWhite BarrowsArgus Press Software (APS) (ASP), Personal Software (Argus Specialist Publications Ltd.) (ASP)W/WhiteBarrows-2256.ssdRAdventureText, Text Adventure, RPG1982Andrew Thomas, Gareth Callister11NY0<p>White Barrows is an adaptation of <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hunt_the_Wumpus">Hunt The Wumpus</a>, the 1975 game by Gregory Yob.</p> <p>This game was later adapted for the Acorn Atom by Andrew Thomas and Gareth Callister.</p> <p>The Atom listing was then converted for the BBC Micro, and printed in "Personal Software" magazine issue 1, Summer 1982.</p> <p>This was then expanded and released commercially in 1983 by ASP Software.</p>

2294DISC999Ingrid's Back Picture Disc (Gnome Ranger II)Level 9 ComputingI/IngridsBackPictureDisc-2294.ssdRAdventureText, Text Adventure, Graphics1988Graham Jones, John Jones-Steele, Mike Austin, Mike Bryant, Nick Austin, Pete AustinGnome Ranger 211Graphics only shown on a Master, or BBC with 48K Ram minimumNYThis disc contains the pictures for the adventure game <a href="http://bbcmicro.co.uk/game.php?id=2132">Ingrids Back</a>. 2296DISC999Chart ChallengeOutlook EnterprisesC/ChartChallenge-2296.ssdRQuizPop Music Quiz1986Steve CloseSTDChart Challenge 112NY0<p>The game needs to write some configuration data to the disc. To play offline, download the disc-image as usual but then disable write-protection in your emulator before running the game.</p> <p>The discs below contain additional questions. Insert the main game disc into drive 0 and one of these database discs into drive 1.</p> <ul> <li><a href="game.php?id=2297">Chart Challenge Database Disc 1</a></li> <li><a href="game.php?id=2298">Chart Challenge Database Disc 2</a></li> <li><a href="game.php?id=2299">Chart Challenge Database Disc 3</a></li> <li><a href="game.php?id=2300">Chart Challenge Database Disc 4</a></li> </ul>
2297DISC999Chart Challenge Database Disc 1Outlook EnterprisesC/ChartChallengeDatabaseDisc1-2297.ssdRQuiz Database DiscPop Music Quiz1986Steve Close12NY0<p>This is an additional database disc for the Chart Challenge pop music quiz. The program writes configuration to disc before it starts the quiz. To play offline, download this disc-image and the <a href="game.php?id=2296">Chart Challenge</a> disc-image, and open them in an emulator. <a href="game.php?id=2296">Chart Challenge</a> needs to be inserted into drive 0, and this database disc needs to be in drive 1.</p>

237611DISCA01Defender (AKA Planetoid)AcornsoftD/Defender-2376.ssdRSpace Shooter (Scrolling)Defender1982Neil Raine11V1.0NY0<p>This original release was withdrawn and re-launched under the title "Planetoid" due to copyright issues with Williams.</p> <p>The later releases also cured the "clumping aliens" issue that could affect some machines.</p> <p>Planetoid is a clone of the 1980 arcade game&nbsp;<a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gss3lxeqCok">Defender</a> from Williams.</p>

2486138DISCA07Kamikaze (AKA Planes)A&F SoftwareK/Kamikaze-2486.ssdRShooter (Gallery)Galaxian1983Brian Clark, Marian Clark11NY0<p>This game was released by A&amp;F Software as 'Kamikaze' for the Electron, and 'Planes' for the BBC Micro.</p> <p>This version is simply Planes with a different title screen, rather than the actual Electron game Kamikaze.</p> <p>The reason is that the Electron game plays insanely fast on the BBC micro.</p>

2552DISC999Gnome Ranger Picture DiscLevel 9 ComputingG/GnomeRangerPictureDisc-2552.ssdRAdventureText, Graphics, Text Adventure1987Pete Austin, Mike Austin, Mike BryantSTDGnome Ranger 111Graphics only shown on a Master, or BBC with 48K Ram minimumNY<p>This disc contains the pictures for the adventure game <a href="http://bbcmicro.co.uk/game.php?id=2551">Gnome Ranger</a>. It can't be played online. To see the pictures, download this disc, and <a href="http://bbcmicro.co.uk/game.php?id=2551">Gnome Ranger</a>, and once the adventure game has loaded swap this disc into the disc drive.</p>

2659DISC999Arkham-Innsmouth And BeyondVirgin BooksA/ArkhamInnsmouthAndBeyond-2659.ssdBAdventureText, Text Adventure1984Stephen LoughranAdventures for your BBC Micro (BOOK)11NY0<p>Published in the "Virgin Computer Series" book "Adventures for your BBC Micro" by Alex Gollner, which contains the following description:</p> <blockquote> <p>This long and intricate adventure by Stephen Loughran is&nbsp;based on the fantasy writings of H. P. Lovecraft, who wrote eerie horror stories about mysterious long-dead civilisations and all-powerful evil gods out to destroy you at the mere mention of their name. Though not in the sword-and-sorcery vein, this scenario is just as exciting &mdash; anything might happen . . .</p> <p>Your aim is to get all the money you can, then find safety. The commands can be entered in upper or lower case. Instructions are included in the program.</p> <p>There is a feature for disc users &mdash; you can create macros. Macros are used when you wish to save a &lsquo;routine&rsquo;, such as the commands to go into a creature&rsquo;s lair and kill it. If you enter &lsquo;MACRO killcrea&rsquo;, enter the commands to kill the creature and then enter &lsquo;END MACRO&rsquo; &mdash; the routine will be stored on disc. This is useful if you go on to another part of the adventure and are &lsquo;killed&rsquo; because you can enter the creature&rsquo;s lair and kill it just by typing the command &lsquo;killcrea&rsquo;. These macros, are stored on disc &mdash; if you do not have a disc interface you need not enter the lines followed by a colon (:) which deal with macros.</p> </blockquote>
2660DISC118Connect Four (AKA Connect 4)Your Computer (IPC Electrical-Electronic Press Ltd.)C/ConnectFour-2660.ssdMTraditional Games (Connect 4)Connect 4198411NYPublished in Your Computer Magazine volume 4 issue 3 in March 1984.

2663DISC999BugbustersVirgin BooksB/Bugbusters-2663.ssdBAdventureText, Text Adventure1984Alex GollnerAdventures for your BBC Micro (BOOK)11NY0<p>Published in the "Virgin Computer Series" book Adventures for your BBC Micro by Alex Gollner, along with the following description:</p> <blockquote> <p>In this original game you have the chance to explore the innards of your computer, for it has started to go wrong! You can now discover what really makes your computer tick and what can cause it to malfunction.</p> <p>Fortunately, your great aunt has just given you one of her strange inventions &mdash; a shrink beam: Once you have shrunk to the right size you must carefully find your way into the computer; then, using all your faculties, you must repair it.</p> <p>This is an example of how adventures need not always involve dungeons!</p> </blockquote>

26672717DISC118Christmas Lights (AKA Candle Light)Micro User, The (later Acorn Computing) (Database Publications)C/ChristmasLights-2667.ssdRPlatformerQ*Bert1986Gordon J. KeyChristmas Crackers 198611NY0<p>Part of <a href="http://bbcmicro.co.uk/game.php?id=2717">Christmas Crackers</a></p> <p>First advertised for sale in Micro User magazine (volume 4, issue 10) in December 1986.&nbsp;Note that Micro User had used the "Christmas Crackers" name before, for <a href="game.php?id=2785">a different compilation</a> first released in 1983.</p> <p>The 1986 compilation comprised Snowplough, Snap, Candle Light, Jet Set Santa, Pull The Cracker, and Name The Carol.</p>
2668DISC118Know Your Own Psi-QMirrorsoft, Ivan Berg SoftwareK/KnowYourOwnPsiQ-2668.ssdRLeisureQuiz, Questionnaire1984Hans Eysenck, Carl SargentSTD11NY
2669DISC999Night School (AKA School's Out)Virgin BooksN/NightSchool-2669.ssdBAdventureText, Text Adventure1984David EstallAdventures for your BBC Micro (BOOK)11NY0<p>Published in the "Virgin Computer Series" book Adventures for your BBC Micro by Alex Gollner as "Night School". The book contains the following description:</p> <blockquote> <p>Just when you thought you had the school computer to yourself an underling of the headmaster calls you to his office. He accuses you of programming the computer system to randomly print smutty language on the terminals while the first years were having an Information Technology lesson.&nbsp; Although you are innocent your protestations fall on deaf ears. You are sentenced to a three-hour detention for the next three nights.</p> <p>As you have been a model pupil you have never stayed after school before &mdash; had you any inkling of what really went on at the school you would never have stayed until the end of the day. After dark your school undergoes a horrible transformation. Familiar objects turn nasty. Death stalks the school corridor. Will you escape with your life?</p> <p>Instructions are included in the program &mdash; your commands should be entered in lower case.</p> </blockquote>
2670DISC118SimonSalamanderS/Simon-2670.ssdRMemory GameTraditional Games, Simon1983Andrew PymerGames Compendium B111NY
2671DISC118Santa And The Snowman (AKA Santa And The Snowmen) (AKA Father Christmas vs The Snowman)Micro User, The (later Acorn Computing) (Database Publications)S/SantaAndTheSnowman-2671.ssdMTraditional Games (Connect 4)Connect 41987Jonathan Perry22NY0<p>Published in Micro User Magazine vol.5 issue 10 in December 1987</p>
2672DISC999Pearl DiverVirgin BooksP/PearlDiver-2672.ssdBAdventureText, Text Adventure1984Alex Gollner, Clive GiffordAdventures for your BBC Micro (BOOK)11NY0<p>Published in the "Virgin Computer Series" books "Adventures for your BBC Micro" by Alex Gollner.</p> <p>Based on a program written by Clive Gifford.</p> <p>The description inn the book reads:</p> <blockquote> <p>As you drain your last pint of the night at the pub you hear talk of pearls down in Bight cove. Disappointed with your meagre catch of fish in the straights of Dogger, you had come to the Seamen&rsquo;s Arms to drown your sorrows in ale. But this news of pearls has given you an aim &mdash; to go out early the next morning to see what you can find; who knows, you might return with a boatful of riches!</p> <p>When you arrive at the cove you must retrieve each oyster separately &mdash; the oysters are of such a size that you must collect them one by one. As you are only a poor fisherman you must make do with a small oxygen tank &mdash; enough just for 90 minutes of searching. Avoiding hazards costs time, but you may be lucky enough to find an old air tank on the sea bottom which will add a few extra minutes to your dwindling strength.</p> <p>In order to recover all five oysters you should map your journey through the deeps, or you may never see the sun again. The cove holds many dangers for the unwary diver . . . Good luck!</p> </blockquote>
2673DISC118ReversiBeebug Magazine (Beebug Publications Ltd.), Elbug Magazine (Beebug Publications Ltd.)R/Reversi-2673.ssdMBoard Game (Reversi)Reversi1983John Webb11VB1.1NY0Sold by Beebugsoft. 26742717DISC118Snow Plough!Micro User, The (later Acorn Computing) (Database Publications)S/SnowPlough-2674.ssdMMazeAvoid 'em, Arcade1986Roland WaddiloveChristmas Crackers 198611NY0<p>Part of <a href="http://bbcmicro.co.uk/game.php?id=2717">Christmas Crackers</a></p> <p>First advertised for sale in Micro User magazine (volume 4, issue 10) in December 1986.&nbsp;Note that Micro User had used the "Christmas Crackers" name before, for <a href="game.php?id=2785">a different compilation</a> first released in 1983.</p> <p>The 1986 compilation comprised Snowplough, Snap, Candle Light, Jet Set Santa, Pull The Cracker, and Name The Carol.</p>

2676DISC999TheSix Keys Of Tarkus (AKA The Seven Keys Of Tarkus)Virgin BooksS/SixKeysOfTarkus-2676.ssdBAdventureText, Text Adventure1984Alex GollnerAdventures for your BBC Micro (BOOK)11NY0<p>Published in the "Virgin Computer Series" books "Adventures for your BBC Micro" by Alex Gollner, which contains the following description:</p> <blockquote> <p>After many days of travel over the northern wastes, you have arrived at the mountains of Tarkus. Barren and windswept, these were once the home of a warrior race who perished long ago. The halls of Tarkus are your destination; there you must free an errant god&rsquo;s soul.</p> <p>Many years ago the people of Tarkus cast great and powerful spells over their kingdom to ward against the gods who wished to control their destiny. Once the Tarks had disappeared their land became the dungeon of the gods. Loki had angered Odin once too often &mdash; he had been taken to Tarkus by fighting men and locked inside a casket in the deepest room of the maze (the capital of Tarkus).</p> <p>Thousands of years later the gods decree that Loki has served his sentence and they choose you to be his liberator. You must go into their underground city and roam the labyrinth of chambers searching for the six keys that open Loki&rsquo;s box. Then you must find the hidden room and release Loki from his prison.</p> <p>A hint before you enter the halls of Tarkus: map your progress or you will lose your way and wander around Tarkus for ever! Good luck!</p> </blockquote>
2677DISC999Trouble In ParadiseVirgin BooksT/TroubleInParadise-2677.ssdBAdventureText, Text Adventure1984Alex GollnerAdventures for your BBC Micro (BOOK)11NY0<p>Published in the "Virgin Computer Series" book "Adventures for your BBC Micro" by Alex Gollner, which contains the following description:</p> <blockquote> <p>&lsquo;Z&rsquo; has sent you on your most deadly mission yet; as the Service&rsquo;s top agent you are the only one capable of handling the situation. You must go to your hotel room in Zakynthos and then discover what your mission is.</p> <p>This complicated adventure is set on the Greek island of Zante, where mysterious plots are afoot. If you do not act &lsquo;normally&rsquo; you will be found out immediately and shot as a spy. There are many red herrings; you must piece together the messages or you may end up dead. Watch your time and your strength closely &mdash; you will need both!</p> </blockquote>

2696DISC120Aircraft Landing Simulator (AKA Aircraft Lander)Personal Computer World (PCW) (VNU Publications), Century Communications Ltd.A/AircraftLandingSimulator-2696.ssdBSimulation (Flight)Flight Simulator1983Paul Bailey, James ByrneBest Of PCW Software For The BBC Micro (BOOK), PCW Games Collection (BOOK)11NYY<p>Originally authored by Paul Bailey for the Video Genie, and converted for the BBC Micro by James Byrne.</p> <p>The original Video Genie listing was published in the "Summer 1983" issue 1 of Personal Computer Games magazine.</p> <p>Published on the <a href="index.php?rt_R=&amp;rt_B=&amp;rt_M=&amp;rt_P=&amp;rt_U=&amp;rt_W=&amp;rt_L=&amp;search=best+of+software&amp;on_T=on&amp;on_Y=on&amp;on_P=on&amp;on_A=on&amp;on_G=on&amp;on_S=on&amp;on_Z=on&amp;on_C=on&amp;sort=a">Best of PCW Software for the BBC Micro</a> compilation from Personal Computer World magazine.</p> <p>Also Published on the <a href="index.php?rt_R=&amp;rt_B=&amp;rt_M=&amp;rt_P=&amp;rt_U=&amp;rt_W=&amp;rt_L=&amp;search=pcw+games+collection&amp;on_T=on&amp;on_Y=on&amp;on_P=on&amp;on_A=on&amp;on_G=on&amp;on_S=on&amp;on_Z=on&amp;on_C=on&amp;sort=a">PCW Games Collection</a> from Personal Computer World magazine.</p> <p>These compilation cassettes were published by Century Communications Ltd.</p> <p>The PCW book accompanying the <em>Best of PCW Software For The BBC Micro</em> contained the following description:</p> <blockquote> <p>This program puts you in the position of a pilot faced with landing his aircraft safely on the airport runway. By using different control keys the plane has to be guided down at the right speed, and at the right time, to ensure safe arrival of all aboard.</p> <p>A continuous display provides a pilot's eye view of the approaching runway. In addition, a number of instrument readings give essential details of such things as altitude, speed, direction, pitch, roll, and distance from the runway. Keys may be used to manoeuvre the aeroplane in terms of its speed, roll and pitch, the pilot's efforts being reflected in the instrument readings. Realistic sound effects accompany the simulation, which will soon discover whether you can say with honesty "I'll take good care of you!"</p> </blockquote> <p>The identical description was also contained in the book accompanying the <em>PCW Games Collection</em>, which also added the following:</p> <blockquote> <h3>Flying tips</h3> <p>The distance reading indicates the distance you are from the end of the runway. As the runway is 2000m long you must touch down when this reads 2000m or less. At touchdown, yaw speed must be between 45m/s and 55m/s. Your pitch and roll must be less than 3 degrees and since the runway is 100m wide, the deviation readout must be within +/- 150m. After touchdown, you can use the rudder to correct the direction of travel, and your brakes to slow down to zero.</p> <p>Your instruments give the following information:</p> <p style="padding-left: 30px;">SPEED airspeed in metres per second (m/s).<br />BEAR bearing is the direction in which yaw aircraft pointing: 0 = straight ahead, positive values to the right, negative to the left (in degrees).<br />PITCH negative values when the aircraft's nose is pointing down, positive when up.<br />ROLL roll causes the banking to change, which alters the aircraft's bearing; positive values clockwise, negative clockwise.<br />ALT height above ground in metres.<br />DIST distance from the far end of the runway in metres.<br />DEV sideways deviation from the centre of the runway.</p> <h3>Controls</h3> <p style="padding-left: 30px;">F = Roll to left<br />G = Maintain roll<br />H = Roll to fight<br />M = Nose up<br />K = Maintain pitch<br />O = Nose down<br />0-9 = Throttle control</p> </blockquote>

2717DISC999Christmas Crackers (Snowplough, Snap, Candle Light, Jet Set Santa, Pull The Cracker, Name The Carol)Micro User, The (later Acorn Computing) (Database Publications)C/ChristmasCrackers-2717.ssdRCompilationMaze, Quiz, Card Game, Q*Bert, Jet Pac, Button basher1986Christmas Crackers 198612NYN<p>First advertised for sale in Micro User magazine (volume 4, issue 10) in December 1986.&nbsp;Note that Micro User had used the "Christmas Crackers" name before, for <a href="game.php?id=2785">a different compilation</a> first released in 1983.</p> <p>The 1986 compilation comprised Snowplough, Snap, Candle Light, Jet Set Santa, Pull The Cracker, and Name The Carol.</p>
2718DISC999Acorn User One-Line Games (Escape From Voros, Lexxias, Race To Varpon, Storm Clouds Over Zaqqit, Zander (AKA Lurch))Acorn User (later BBC Acorn User) (Redwood Publishing Ltd.)A/AcornUserOneLineGames-2718.ssdMArcadeDriving, Catch 'em, Avoid 'em, Bomber, One-liner, Prank1987David Lawrence, Stan Froco, Oscar Rune11NYN<p>Published in the "Acorn Abuser's Diary" section of Acorn User magazine between May and November of 1987, these games consist of a single line of BASIC code each. David Lawrence was credited as the author of the first game, which was retrospectively titled "Escape From Voros". Oscar Rune and Stan Froco were later named as the authors of Varpon and Lurch respectively, on the <a href="game.php?id=2757">Acorn User Games Disc</a>.</p> <p>The fifth game, Zander (AKA Lurch), is a parody of the early Archimedes game Zarch (aka Lander). It's extra-unplayable because it runs far too fast and you have to start hitting RETURN within the first second or you'll crash into terrain.</p> <p>Escape From Voros: May 1987</p> <p>Lexxias: June 1987</p> <p>Race To Varpon: July 1987</p> <p>Storm Clouds Over Zaqqit: September 1987</p> <p>Zander (AKA Lurch): November 1987 (The game was named Lurch on the Acorn User Games Disc.)</p> <p>Also note that Acorn User released another one-line game, titled Mastermind, which appeared on the <a href="game.php?id=2757">Acorn User Games Disc</a></p> <p>At the time of writing, it is not known which issue (if any) of Acorn User the game appeared in.</p>
2719DISC121PhoenixRetro SoftwareP/Phoenix-2719.ssdPShooter (Gallery)Phoenix2017Richard BroadhurstO11NYY<p>A conversion of <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phoenix_(video_game)">the arcade game</a>.</p> <p><a href="http://www.retrosoftware.co.uk/forum/viewtopic.php?f=19&amp;t=909">More details</a>&nbsp;at Retro Software, and at&nbsp;<a href="http://www.stardot.org.uk/forums/viewtopic.php?f=57&amp;t=8416&amp;hilit=Phoenix">Stardot Forums.</a></p>

2726DISC121RobotankPersonal Computer World (PCW) (VNU Publications), Century Communications Ltd.R/Robotank-2726.ssdBStrategy1984James Byrne, Bryn PhillipsPCW Games Collection (BOOK)11NY0<p>Originally authored by Bryn Phillips and converted to the BBC Micro by James Byrne</p> <p>Published on the <a href="index.php?rt_R=&amp;rt_B=&amp;rt_M=&amp;rt_P=&amp;rt_U=&amp;rt_W=&amp;rt_L=&amp;search=pcw+games+collection&amp;on_T=on&amp;on_Y=on&amp;on_P=on&amp;on_A=on&amp;on_G=on&amp;on_S=on&amp;on_Z=on&amp;on_C=on&amp;sort=a">PCW Games Collectio</a>n from Personal Computer World magazine.</p> <p>These compilation cassettes were published by Century Communications Ltd.</p> <p>The PCW book accompanying the <em>PCW Games Collection</em> contained the following description:</p> <blockquote> <p>Robotank is an original strategy game for the BBC Micro, The idea is to drive your tank around a battlefield, strewn with a number of targets. You have to destroy as many of them as possible in five missions.</p> <p>On starting the game the battlefield will be drawn, containing a number of targets including enemy tanks, huts and guns. Your Robotank will be placed at the bottom left of the screen.</p> <p>The idea of the game is to program the tank with a series of Logo style commands in order to destroy as many targets as possible. The available commands are:</p> <p style="padding-left: 30px;">F - Forward one length<br />R - Turn fight 90 degrees<br />L - Turn left 90 degrees<br />S - Shoot<br />P - Program complete - GO<br />D - Delete last instruction</p> <p>For example, the following simple program: FFFRSLFFS, would make the tank move forward three lengths, turn fight 90 degrees, shoot, ram left 90 degrees, move two lengths forward and shoot again.</p> <p>The maximum Robotank program is 40 commands, and once the tank has been started it cannot be stopped. If the tank crashes into any obstacles, the game will end; otherwise, you have five runs in which to destroy all the targets. The points value of the targets increases with each hit, so careful planning is required to achieve high scores.</p> </blockquote> <p>&nbsp;</p>
2727DISC121Chocky EggHome Computing Weekly (Argus Specialist Publications Ltd.) (ASP)C/ChockyEgg-2727.ssdMArcade1984Dave Carlos, Jon Revis11NY0<p>Published in issue 58 of Home Computing Weekly in April 1984.</p>

2729DISC121ADay At The Races (AKA Race Day)Acorn Computing (formerly The Micro User) (Europress Publications)D/DayAtTheRaces-2729.ssdMSport (Horse Racing)Gambling1993Bruce Goatly110NY0<p>Given away on the BBC Subscribers disc in Acorn Computing (Formerly The Micro User Magazine) vol.11 issue 8 in October 1993.</p>
2730DISC121Target PracticePersonal Computer World (PCW) (VNU Publications), Century Communications Ltd.T/TargetPractice-2730.ssdBShooter (Gallery)1983Leon Goodfriend, Gordon MillsBest Of PCW Software For The BBC Micro (BOOK)22NYY<p>Originally authored by Gordon Mills, and converted for the BBC Micro by Leon Goodfriend.</p> <p>Published on the <a href="index.php?rt_R=&amp;rt_B=&amp;rt_M=&amp;rt_P=&amp;rt_U=&amp;rt_W=&amp;rt_L=&amp;search=best+of+PCW+software&amp;on_T=on&amp;on_Y=on&amp;on_P=on&amp;on_A=on&amp;on_G=on&amp;on_S=on&amp;on_Z=on&amp;on_C=on&amp;sort=a">Best of PCW software for the BBC Micro</a> compilation from Personal Computer World magazine.</p> <p>These compilation cassettes were published by Century Communications Ltd.</p> <p>The accompanying book contained the following description:</p> <blockquote> <p>This is a game for two players, in which the object is to obliterate 10 randomly placed targets with 15 missiles, the missile launcher moving across the bottom of the screen at variable speed.</p> <p>After providing their names, the players have to select the speed at which their missile launcher is to move: this can be anything from a gentle plod to a definite whoo-oosh! Missiles are launched by pressing a key; their journey towards the target and, with luck and skill, the eventual explosion, are accompanied by some realistic sound effects. A count of how many missiles each player has left is shown throughout.</p> </blockquote>

2734DISC121Tea-Bag Terror (AKA Tea Bag Terror)Self-publishedT/TeaBagTerror-2734.ssdPMazePac-Man, Arcade2015Stuart Johns (@forgotten_grove), Roland Waddilove11YesNY0<p>Based on "Money Maze" by Roland Waddilove, which was published in Electron User Magazine vol.1 issue 9 in June 1984, and later released by Alternative Software on the Triple Decker 10 compilation.</p>

2757DISC999Acorn User Games DiscAcorn User (later BBC Acorn User) (Redwood Publishing Ltd.)A/AcornUserGamesDisc-2757.dsdRCompilationPlatformer, Adventure, Puzzle, Mastermind, Text Adventure, Traditional Games (Connect 4)1988Peter Voke, David Lawton, Phil Martin, Mark de Weger, David Acton, David Lawrence, Don Scales, Oscar Rune, Stan Froco, Orson FactAcorn User Games Disc11NY0<p>This disc was first advertised for sale in Acorn User magazine in October 1988.</p> <p>It consists of previously published Acorn User games:&nbsp;<a href="game.php?id=2254">Warlord</a> (Peter Voke), <a href="game.php?id=738">Wizalon</a> (David Lawton), <a href="game.php?id=391">Run Silent, Run Deep</a> (Phil Martin), <a href="game.php?id=1207">Castle of Nightmares</a> (Mark de Weger), <a href="game.php?id=1077">Quadline</a> (David Acton), <a href="game.php?id=2737">3D Pentominoes (AKA Polyominoes)</a> (David Lawrence/Don Scales), <a href="game.php?id=2718">Race to Varpon</a> (Oscar Rune), <a href="game.php?id=1486">Maze</a> (David Lawrence), Mastermind (Orson Fact), and&nbsp;<a href="game.php?id=2718">Lurch</a> (Stan Froco).</p> <p>Orson Fact is a made-up name. It is an anagram of Stan Froco.</p> <p>All of the <a href="http://bbcmicro.co.uk/game.php?id=2718">one-line games</a> previously appeared in the Acorn User "Acorn Abuser's Diary" section, but at the time of writing it is not known which issue (if any), the Mastermind game was published.</p>
2758DISC122Beeb PatiencePersonal Computer World (PCW) (VNU Publications), Century Communications Ltd.B/BeebPatience-2758.ssdBCard GamePatience1983Benny Notarianni, Richard StillBest Of PCW Software For The BBC Micro (BOOK)11NY0<p>Originally authored by Richard Still, and converted to the BBC Micro by Benny Notarianni.</p> <p>Published on the <a href="index.php?rt_R=&amp;rt_B=&amp;rt_M=&amp;rt_P=&amp;rt_U=&amp;rt_W=&amp;rt_L=&amp;search=best+of+PCW+software&amp;on_T=on&amp;on_Y=on&amp;on_P=on&amp;on_A=on&amp;on_G=on&amp;on_S=on&amp;on_Z=on&amp;on_C=on&amp;sort=a">Best of PCW software for the BBC Micro</a> compilation from Personal Computer World magazine.</p> <p>These compilation cassettes were published by Century Communications Ltd.</p> <p>The book accompanying the Best of PCW software for the BBC Micro contained the following description:</p> <blockquote> <p>The user plays a game of Patience on the screen. The object is to place each suit in ascending order on its respective pile.</p> <p>Instructions are displayed, then the main program is called. (It is not possible to look at the instructions again without rewinding the tape.) The single pack is laid out in the form of a 'Harp'. The cards may be moved from one column to another or new cards are dealt from the stack. As soon as an Ace becomes available, it may be used to start a file.</p> <p>No false moves or cheating are allowed! Perhaps a 'Cheat' facility could be added for desperate players?</p> </blockquote>

2773DISC123ConvoyPersonal Computer World (PCW) (VNU Publications), Century Communications Ltd.C/Convoy-2773.ssdBShooter (Gallery)Trajectory, Worms1983Jeff Aughton, James ByrneBest Of PCW Software For The BBC Micro (BOOK)11NY0<p>Originally authored by Jeff Aughton, and converted for the BBC Micro by James Byrne.</p> <p>Published on the <a href="index.php?rt_R=&amp;rt_B=&amp;rt_M=&amp;rt_P=&amp;rt_U=&amp;rt_W=&amp;rt_L=&amp;search=best+of+PCW+software&amp;on_T=on&amp;on_Y=on&amp;on_P=on&amp;on_A=on&amp;on_G=on&amp;on_S=on&amp;on_Z=on&amp;on_C=on&amp;sort=a">Best of PCW software for the BBC Micro</a> compilation from Personal Computer World magazine.</p> <p>These compilation cassettes were published by Century Communications Ltd.</p> <p>The PCW book accompanying the <em>Best of PCW Software For The BBC Micro</em> cassette contained the following description:</p> <blockquote> <p>You are the commander of a large land-based gun which must be used to shell a convoy of submarines. The submarines are trying to find their way through some narrow straits and your task is to destroy them all before they escape your range. If you successfully destroy a fleet of subs, then you can go on to try your aim at larger convoys.</p> <p>You aim your gun by controlling its elevation and bearing. The elevation of your gun affects how far the shells travel, and the bearing affects their direction. Instructions on which keys are used to effect this control appear on the screen when the program is first run.</p> </blockquote>

2785DISC999Christmas CrackersMicro User, The (later Acorn Computing) (Database Publications)C/ChristmasCrackers-2785.dsdRCompilationMaze, Quiz, Card Game, Snake, Simon1983Christmas Crackers 198311NY0<p>First advertised for sale in Micro User magazine (volume 1, issue 9) in November 1983. 2802DISC999Adventure 200Foilkade Ltd.A/Adventure200-2802.ssdRAdventureText, Text Adventure1982C.J. Coombs11YY0<p>"OVER 200 PLACES to explore. Written in machine code and using advanced data compression techniques it squeezes a true fixed-map adventure into just 16K &ndash; all held in ram &ndash; no extra cassette reads or books of text. Unlike a randomly generated maze type game this is a real test of your tactical skill. It starts easy but the further you progress the more dangerous and difficult the problems become as you use objects around you to overcome obstacles and you are the hero! Flexible command format allows abbreviation multiple word lines." [sic]</p> <p>&ndash; <a href="https://archive.org/stream/ComputerAndVideoGamesIssue018Apr83/Computer_And_Video_Games_Issue_018_Apr_83#page/n110/mode/1up/">Advertisement</a> in Computer And Video Games magazine, issue 10, April 1983</p> <p>&nbsp;</p>
