2881DISC999One Room (AKA Oneroom)FalsoftO/OneRoom-2881.ssdBAdventureText, Text Adventure1983Jorge Mir, Lurkio, AntRainbow Book Of Adventures (BOOK)11NYY<p>One Room might be the first room-escape game. It might even be the first one-room text adventure game. What's certain is that it was written in 32K Extended Color BASIC for the TRS-80 Color Computer and published in the <a href="https://archive.org/stream/RainbowBookAdventures/Rainbow%20Book%20Adventures#page/n59/mode/2up">Rainbow Book Of Adventures</a> in 1983.&nbsp;</p> <p>The game was ported to BBC BASIC for the BBC Micro computer in 2018.</p> <p>More details on&nbsp;<a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FuJQqBVZGnw">YouTube</a>, at&nbsp;<a href="https://ahopeful.wordpress.com/2018/08/10/one-room-1983-the-first-one-room-game/">Retroactive Fiction</a>, at&nbsp;<a href="https://stardot.org.uk/forums/viewtopic.php?f=40&amp;t=15340&amp;p=208505&amp;hilit=one%20room#p208505">Stardot</a>, at&nbsp;<a href="http://ifdb.tads.org/viewgame?id=8mby8zffji4ah3di">IFDB</a>, at&nbsp;<a href="http://solutionarchive.com/game/id%2C7761/One+Room.html">CASA</a>, and at&nbsp;<a href="https://www.intfiction.org/forum/viewtopic.php?f=4&amp;t=26431#p142646">IntFiction.org</a>.&nbsp;</p>
288296DISCA11Frak!AardvarkF/Frak-2882.ssdRPlatformer1986Nick Pelling (Orlando)STTPlay It Again Sam 0411YesV2.1NY0<p>This is the original Acorn Electron version of Frak from Aardvark Software.</p>
2883DISC999Lighthouse AdventureFalsoftL/LighthouseAdventure-2883.ssdBAdventureText, Text Adventure1983Chris WilkinsonRainbow Book Of Adventures (BOOK)11NY0<p>Lighthouse adventure is a text adventure game written in BASIC for the TRS-80 Color Computer. It was published in the <a href="https://archive.org/stream/RainbowBookAdventures/Rainbow%20Book%20Adventures#page/n23/mode/2up">Rainbow Book Of Adventures</a> in 1983.&nbsp;</p> <p>The game was <a href="https://stardot.org.uk/forums/viewtopic.php?f=40&amp;t=15340&amp;p=213068#p212560">ported</a> to BBC BASIC for the BBC Micro computer in 2018.</p> <p>The book contains the following description:</p> <p>&nbsp;</p> <blockquote> <p>In the late 1700's an old English ship carrying jewels and gold was seized by pirates in a violent storm. The crew, weak and sick from the long journey, could not properly defend the ship and her invaluable cargo. The pirates killed everyone on board and set sail for America.</p> <p>&nbsp; Months later, they arrived off the coast of a New England peninsula and smuggled the priceless gold on shore. They quickly found a hiding place for the treasure. According to the legend, no one ever found the smugglers or the treasure, but most people believe the gold is located in or near the lighthouse. Over the years, many have tried unsuccsessfully to find the legendary gold, but either quit, or died in the quest.</p> <p>&nbsp; This exciting adventure leads you on a magical hunt to find the smugglers hideout, take the treasure and make your getaway. You will encounter many tips along the journey, and here's a helpful one before you begin: The British call it a "trolley", but in America, we call it a "dolly".</p> </blockquote>

2887DISC126Under The MortuaryPopular Computing Weekly (Sunshine Publications Ltd.)U/UnderTheMortuary-2887.ssdMArcade Adventure1986Sunil Jagota11NYN<p>Published over four issues of Popular Computing Weekly magazine: volume 5, issues 6, 7, 8, and 9 (February 6th, 13th, 20th, and 27th, 1986).</p> <p>In <a href="https://www.linkedin.com/in/suniljagota/">his LinkedIn profile</a>, the author Sunil Jagota says, "I wrote my first flight simulator at the age of 14 and had written and published my first arcade adventure game written in 6502 machine code by the time I was 15. I am still just as passionate about technology as I was then."</p>

2895DISC999Frak! [hack]ZentrixF/Frakhack-2895.ssdLPlatformer1989Nick Pelling (Orlando)STT11YesNY0<p>This is a modification of the original Acorn Electron version of Aardvark Software's Frak.&nbsp;This hack from 1989 gives the player many ways to cheat!&nbsp;The cheats come from the commercially available "Cheat It Again Joe 4" cheats disc, sold by Zentrix Software. (The first 3 "Cheat It Again Joe" cheat compilations were published by Impact Software.) All the "Cheat It Again Joe" tapes and discs were the brainchild of Mark Gidley.</p>
2896DISC999Silverton HouseFalsoftS/SilvertonHouse-2896.ssdBAdventureText, Text Adventure1985John Everest, Pat EverestSecond Rainbow Book Of Adventures (BOOK)11NY0<p>Silverton House is a text adventure game written in BASIC for the TRS-80 Color Computer. It was published in the <a href="https://archive.org/stream/secondrainbowboo00char#page/n219">Second Rainbow Book Of Adventures</a> in 1985.&nbsp;</p> <p>The game was <a href="https://stardot.org.uk/forums/viewtopic.php?f=40&amp;t=15666&amp;p=214278&amp;hilit=silverton#p214278">ported</a> to BBC BASIC for the BBC Micro computer in 2018.</p>
2897DISC999Mystery Of The Java StarShards SoftwareM/MysteryOfTheJavaStar-2897.ssdRAdventurePuzzle, Educational1984Steve MaltzSTD11NNY<p>See EveryGameGoing.com for&nbsp;<a href="http://www.everygamegoing.com/egg/landingItem/index/machine_type_group_default_folder/electron/publisher_folder/shards/format_folder/tapes/item_title/Mystery-Of-The-Java-Star">instructions and more</a>.</p> <p>Mystery Of The Java Star is only compatible with machines that have PAGE set at &amp;E00, such as a BBC Master 128.</p> <p>(The game was originally released on <em>cassette-tape</em> for the BBC Micro Model B but it can't easily be run from <em>floppy disc</em> with a standard Model B. <a href="https://stardot.org.uk/forums/viewtopic.php?f=1&amp;t=15714&amp;p=215389#p215251">More details</a> at Stardot.)</p>

29282054DISC999Cells And Serpents (Improved)8-Bit Software (8 Bit Software) (8BS), BBC PD, Mad Rabbit Software, Argus Press Software (APS) (ASP), A&B Computing (Argus Specialist Publications Ltd.) (ASP), Computing Today (Argus Specialist Publications Ltd.) (ASP)C/CellsAndSerpents-2928.ssdLRPGText, Text Adventure1991Ian Nicholls, G. Lovell, Roger PashbySTD11NY0<p>This game is the improved modification of the 1983 original BBC Micro release.</p> <p>The BBC micro game is a conversion of "Cells And Serpents", written for the NASCOM computer by G. Lovell, first published in the December 1980 issue of Computing Today magazine.</p> <p>&nbsp;</p> <p>The original, commercial BBC micro release by ASP software was in early 1983. A functionally identical, but much better annotated listing was published in the May/June 1983 issue of A&amp;B Computing (volume 1, issue 1) which credits I.G. Nicholls with the translation.<br />Later, a slightly different listing was published both on the 8BS Public Domain disc 05 in September 1990, and BBC PD Disc 10.<br />An improved version of this listing was published on both BBC PD Disc 166 (which featured Mad Rabbit PD Disc 024) and 8BS Public Domain disc 08 in January 1991 which credits the improvements to Roger Pashby in October 1990.</p>
2929DISC129Air Sea Battle (AKA Sea Battle)Your Computer (IPC Electrical-Electronic Press Ltd.)A/AirSeaBattle-2929.ssdMShooter (Gallery)1982Lakith Leelasena11YY0<p>Published in Your Computer Magazine volume 2 issue 7 in July 1982.</p> <p>The original magazine listing was buggy, and although the author sent in a fix to the September 1982 issue, the game still did not work properly.</p> <p>The game seen here is a close approximation of the author's intentions.</p>

29342785DISC129Snow PudMicro User, The (later Acorn Computing) (Database Publications)S/SnowPud-2934.ssdRMazeAvoid 'em1983Christmas Crackers 198311NY0<p>Part of <a href="game.php?id=2785">Christmas Crackers</a></p> <p>First advertised for sale in Micro User magazine (volume 1, issue 9) in November 1983. Note that Micro User used the "Christmas Crackers" name again, for <a href="game.php?id=2717">a different compilation</a> released in 1986 and again in 1987.</p> <p>&nbsp;</p> <p>The 1983 compilation comprised Sleigh Lander, Christmas Simon, Anagrams, Ski Slope, Carol Quiz, Tic-Tac-Toe, Collect The Trees, Maze Pud, Snow Pud, Chimes, Christmas Word Search, Dodge Dad, Mover, Christmas Keyboard Tester, Blind-Man's Buff, Forest Run, Halves, Turkey Shoot, Crazy Santa, Christmas Snap, and Santa Skittle.</p> <p>&nbsp;</p> <p><a href="game.php?id=2717">The 1986 compilation</a> comprised Snowplough, Snap, Candle Light, Jet Set Santa, Pull The Cracker, and Name The Carol.</p>
2935DISC999Lemonade Stall (AKA Lemonade Stand)Electron User, The (Database Publications)L/LemonadeStall-2935.ssdMSimulation (Business)1987Mark Smiddy11NY0<p>Lemonade Stand is a business simulation game created for "<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lemonade_Stand#Development">time-shared mainframe computers</a>" in 1973 by Bob Jamison of the Minnesota Educational Computing Consortium (MECC). In 1979 the game was ported to the Apple II by Charlie Kellner.&nbsp;Apple included the game with their computers throughout the 1980s. Kellner's source code was released and the game has since been ported to modern computers as a free, open-source game.</p> <p>The Electron and BBC Micro version was published in Electron User magazine, volume 4, issue 12, in September 1987.</p> <p>The Apple II and the BBC Micro versions have not been compared, so it is not known whether Mark Smiddy ported the Apple II version, or simply wrote his own interpretation of the game.</p>
2936DISC132Rat CatchFontana PublishingR/RatCatch-2936.ssdBCatch 'em1984Graham Curling, Tim Hartnell, Ian HuttGiant Book Of Games For Your BBC Micro (BOOK)11NY0<p>Published in the book "The Giant book of games for your BBC micro" from Fontana Publishing, which contains the following description:</p> <blockquote> <p>In this game, based on one written by Graham Curling, you have to guide your rats using the 'Z' and 'X' keys. The rats hold a bucket, and you have to catch falling bricks in this bucket to build up a wall.</p> <p>The points you score increase as the wall gets higher and the bricks change colour. As you'll see when the game is in action, the user-defined graphics are particularly effective.</p> <p>Six catches in a row will gain you a bonus which is added to your score at the end of the game. Six misses in a row costs you a life. You have five lives at the start of the game.</p> <p>There are 300 bricks dropped during each run of the game. The game ends either when you lose your lives, or all 300 bricks have been dropped. The brick tally is clocked up continuously on the screen and there is a high-score facility, so you can try and beat your best score from earlier rounds.</p> </blockquote>

295225DISC999Chuckie Egg 2009 (Level-editor) [hack]Organ Grinder's MonkeyC/ChuckieEgg2009-2952.ssdLPlatformer2009Doug Anderson, Dave Edwards (The Dave)11YesNNY<p>This is Dave Edwards's original Acorn Electron release of Chuckie Egg 2009, which comes with eight new levels for the classic <a href="game.php?id=25">Chuckie Egg</a>. The new levels were designed with the included level-editor, which was also created by Dave Edwards.&nbsp;</p> <p>Chuckie Egg 2009 was published on the 8BS public-domain disc TBI-185.</p> <p>The new levels (<em>without</em> the level-editor) were published on the Electron User Group PD Disc 70 in 2009. They are also available as&nbsp;<a href="game.php?id=1840">a standalone game</a>, which is compatible with the BBC Micro Model B.</p> <p>The level-editor, included in this original release, is compatible with the BBC Master, but <em>not</em> with the Model B.</p>

Reboot the computer by negotiating levels and collecting objects to make the password that resets the machine. A rocket will propel your character upwards and gravity will pull you back down again. Avoid the guardians and keep an eye on the limited fuel! After collecting all the objects, return to the spaceship to advance to the next level.</em></p> <p>A new, original game for the BBC Master.&nbsp;<a href="https://stardot.org.uk/forums/viewtopic.php?f=57&amp;t=15729#p215577">More details</a> at Stardot.</p>

2982DISC131QuadranglePersonal Computer World (PCW) (VNU Publications), Century Communications Ltd.Q/Quadrangle-2982.ssdBTraditional Games (Connect 4)Board Game, Connect 41983Paul Borrett, Eileen Baghoomians, Steven FawthropSTDBest Of PCW Software For The BBC Micro (BOOK)12NY0<p>Original program by Eileen Baghoomians and Steven Fawthrop. Adapted for the BBC Micro by Paul Borrett.</p> <p>Published on the <a href="index.php?rt_R=&amp;rt_B=&amp;rt_M=&amp;rt_P=&amp;rt_U=&amp;rt_W=&amp;rt_L=&amp;search=best+of+PCW+software&amp;on_T=on&amp;on_Y=on&amp;on_P=on&amp;on_A=on&amp;on_G=on&amp;on_S=on&amp;on_Z=on&amp;on_C=on&amp;sort=a">Best of PCW software for the BBC Micro</a> compilation from Personal Computer World magazine.</p> <p>These compilation cassettes were published by Century Communications Ltd.</p> <p>The book accompanying the Best of PCW software for the BBC Micro contained the following description:</p> <blockquote> <p>This is an original, colourful game of the Connect 4 and Othello ilk.</p> <p>The game is played on a 7 by 6 grid, with coloured blocks, the object being to place four of your blocks at the corners of a square before your opponent. Blocks may only be placed on top of each other; they cannot hang in mid-air, and the squares formed may be as small of as large as the grid allows.</p> <p>The program allows for one player to try and beat the computer, or for two players to play each other. If you require advice at any time the computer is very kindly programmed to help you - just press 'H'.</p> <p>Users with a 32K BBC B model with disc unit will need to alter the memory position by entering: PAGE=&amp;E00 (RETURN) before typing in the listing.</p> </blockquote>

2988DISC131Wall Smash (AKA Two-Wall Smash)Fontana PublishingW/WallSmash-2988.ssdBBat And BallBreakout, Pong1984Tim Hartnell, Ian Hutt, Mike O'NeillGiant Book Of Games For Your BBC Micro (BOOK)11NY0<p>From the book "The Giant book of games for your BBC Micro" by Fontana publishing, which contains the following description:</p> <blockquote> <p>This game, patterned after one written by Mike O'Neill, is a two-wall version of the popular arcade game which is often called 'Breakout'.</p> <p>The aim of the game is to destroy all the bricks in the walls by controlling the ball with your bat. The bat moves horizontally at the bottom of the screen. The ball moves at two different angles, and there are three bat sizes. The bat gets smaller as the game progresses - after a certain number of hits, when the ball reaches the second wall and when the ball hits the top of the screen.</p> <p>The colour of the brick determines how much it is worth. The high score displayed on the screen, next to the current score. The number of the ball in play is also shown. The high score is updated at the end of each game.<u></u></p> </blockquote>

2990DISC132BobsleighGranada Technical Books (Granada Publishing Ltd.)B/Bobsleigh-2990.ssdBDrivingDriving (Top Down)1983Mike James, S.M. Gee, Kay Ewbank21 games for the BBC Micro (BOOK)11NY0<p>Published in the book <em>21 games for the BBC micro</em> by Mike James, S. M. Gee and Kay Ewbank, published by <em>Granada publishing Ltd</em>.</p> <p>&nbsp;</p> <p>The book contains the following description:</p> <blockquote> <p>In this game you have to steer your blue bobsleigh down a random course that winds its way past fir trees. You can choose whether to try a course that is easy to manoeuvre or one that is difficult. (There are actually five levels of difficulty which govern the width of the course.) If you crash you&rsquo;ll hear a dismal tone and that round of the game is over. Play this game to see how adept you are at keeping on course.</p> <h3>How to play</h3> <p>The bobsleigh starts off at the top of the course and the course automatically moves past it. You have to steer the bobsleigh using the right and left arrow keys to ensure that you do not crash into the edges of the course. At the beginning of the game you have to select the difficulty level for the game. This governs the width of the course with 1 producing the widest, and therefore easiest, and 5 the narrowest, and most difficult.</p> </blockquote>
2991DISC132CosmosFontana PublishingC/Cosmos-2991.ssdBSpace Shooter (Gallery)1984Tim Hartnell, Ian HuttGiant Book Of Games For Your BBC Micro (BOOK)11NY0<p>Published in "The Giant book of games for your BBC micro" by Fontana publishing, which contains the following description:</p> <blockquote> <p>In this exciting game you are flying over a moving landscape which produces a very good 3-D effect. You have to try and shoot as many alien birds as possible within a limited time. Full instructions are within the game.</p> <p>You move your sights around the galaxy until you spot one of the birds. The birds will try to evade your lethal weaponry.<u></u></p> </blockquote>
2992DISC132Space Invaders (AKA Invaders)Pan Books Ltd., Personal Computer News (PCN) (VNU Publications)S/SpaceInvaders-2992.ssdBSpace Shooter (Gallery)Space Invaders1983Ian ThomasSixty programs for the BBC Micro (BOOK)11NY0<p>Published in the book <em>Sixty Programs for the BBC Micro</em> by <em>Pan Books Ltd</em>, in association with <em>Personal Computer News</em>.</p> <p>The book contains the following description:</p> <blockquote> <p>How could we write a Bumper Book of programs without including the classic Invaders games? Well, here it is complete with shields and Mothership and a screen full of the dreaded Aliens.</p> </blockquote>
2993DISC132Torpedo RunNewnes Technical Books (Butterworth And Co. Ltd.)T/TorpedoRun-2993.ssdBShooter (Gallery)1984Derrick DainesBBC Micro programs in BASIC (BOOK)11NY0<p>Published in the book "BBC micro programs in BASIC" from Newnes technical books, which contains the following description:</p> <blockquote> <p>Here is a great game for those who like shooting games. We suppose the player to be torpedo officer or captain of a warship. He has three torpedo tubes numbered left to right, each with a magazine of nine torpedoes. An infinite array of enemy ships is constantly parading from right to left of the screen. These are of different types, proceeding at different speeds at different distances up the screen. The player simply presses the numeric key 1, 2 or 3 according to which torpedo tube he wishes to fire. The track of the torpedo is then seen progressing up the screen until it either hits a ship or disappears over the horizon. Only one torpedo may be in motion at once and of course the player cannot fire more than the specified nine torpedoes from each tube. At all times there is a visual indication of how many torpedoes remain for each tube, and of the player's score.</p> <p>Scoring depends entirely upon difficulty. That is to say, the leftmost torpedo tube (if successful) scores less than the rightmost. Similarly, slower and larger targets score less than swift small ones, and targets crossing near the bottom of the screen score less than those on the horizon. Thus the game is a real test of skill. The game ends when the player runs out of torpedoes, and the computer retains details of the best six scores and their scorers.</p> </blockquote>

A dot appears on the map and you have to guess which own it is by choosing from the five names that are provided. All you have to do is press the number of the answer that you think is correct, then sit back!</p> </blockquote>

2998DISC132Grand PrixPan Books Ltd., Personal Computer News (PCN) (VNU Publications)G/GrandPrix-2998.ssdBDrivingSprint, Driving (Top Down)1983Paul StanleySixty programs for the BBC Micro (BOOK)11NY0<p>Published in the book <em>Sixty Programs for the BBC Micro</em> by <em>Pan Books Ltd</em>, in association with <em>Personal Computer News</em>.</p> <p>The listing, as printed in the book was faulty, and quite a lot of work has been done to make the game playable as intended by the author.</p> <p>The book contains the following description:</p> <blockquote> <p>After all this intergalactic warfare, you'll find it refreshing to return to Earth and struggle to cope with a fleet of helicopters whose pilots are committed to wiping out your fair city. Thankfully you're in control of the metropolitan laser tower, and it's up to you to shoot down the bombs before they hit the city. You'll get points for every bomb you hit, and whilst you can wipe out a chopper if you feel so inclined, you will not add to your tally by so doing. You move your laser sight with the cursor keys, and the game is over once one of the bombs finds a clear path to the ground or the laser tower itself is destroyed.</p> </blockquote>
2999DISC132Cosmic InvadersFontana PublishingC/CosmicInvaders-2999.ssdBSpace Shooter (Gallery)Space Invaders1984Mark BuckwellGiant Book Of Games For Your BBC Micro (BOOK)11NY0<p>Published in the book "The Giant book of games for your BBC micro" from Fontana Publishing, which contains the following description:</p> <blockquote> <p>Here is a complete implementation of space invaders. Even though it is written in BASIC, and uses MODE 7 graphics, you'll be amazed to see how faithful it is to the arcade original.</p> <p>Full instructions are included in the game, which was written by Mark Bucknell. There are a number of options you can trigger, such as 'freeze/unfreeze' and turning the sound on or off. The SHIFT key is used to fire.</p> </blockquote>

3004DISC132Heli-BomberPan Books Ltd., Personal Computer News (PCN) (VNU Publications)H/HeliBomber-3004.ssdBShooter (Gallery)Bomber1983Ian Thomas, Robert ErskineSixty programs for the BBC Micro (BOOK)11NY0<p>Published in the book <em>Sixty Programs for the BBC Micro</em> by <em>Pan Books Ltd</em>, in association with <em>Personal Computer News</em>.</p> <p>Original program by Robert Erskine, converted for the BBC Micro by Ian Thomas.</p> <p>The book contains the following description:</p> <blockquote> <p>After all this intergalactic warfare, you'll find it refreshing to return to Earth and struggle to cope with a fleet of helicopters whose pilots are committed to wiping out your fair city. Thankfully you're in control of the metropolitan laser tower, and it's up to you to shoot down the bombs before they hit the city. You'll get points for every bomb you hit, and whilst you can wipe out a chopper if you feel so inclined, you will not add to your tally by so doing. You move your laser sight with the cursor keys, and the game is over once one of the bombs finds a clear path to the ground or the laser tower itself is destroyed.</p> </blockquote>
3005DISC132Froggy Go HomeVirgin BooksF/FroggyGoHome-3005.ssdBPlatformerFrogger1983Hugh GollnerMore Games for your BBC Micro (BOOK)11NY0<p>Published in the book <em>More Games For Your BBC Micro</em> by <em>Virgin Books</em> Ltd, which contains the following description:</p> <blockquote> <p>This program, written by Hugh Gollner, is in two parts. To play the game you must initially type in the first part and save it; then type in the second, longer part and save that too. Once you have done that rewind the tape to the beginning. You can then load and run the program by typing CHAIN""</p> <p>The first part of the program defines the user-defined characters and gets the computer ready for the next part. It also includes the instructions. Once you have read these it will load and run the next part and then you can start playing!</p> <p>In this version of the well-known arcade game you have to move a small helpless frog into its home. This may sound simple, but first the frog has to negotiate a busy four-lane motorway and then cross a fast-flowing river by jumping from log to log as they float by.</p> <p>But even with your help, can this brave young frog survive whirlpools that suddenly change the direction of the river? And if so, can he still get home before nightfall?</p> <p>PRESS ANY KEY TO GO ON!</p> </blockquote>

3011DISC133Alien InvadersGranada Technical Books (Granada Publishing Ltd.)A/AlienInvaders-3011.ssdBSpace Shooter (Gallery)Space Invaders1983Mike James, S.M. Gee, Kay Ewbank21 games for the BBC Micro (BOOK)11NY0<p>Published in the book <em>21 games for the BBC micro</em> by Mike James, S. M. Gee and Kay Ewbank, published by <em>Granada publishing Ltd</em>.</p> <p>&nbsp;</p> <p>The book contains the following description:</p> <blockquote> <p>Two types of alien ships are heading towards earth and you have to defend civilisation as we know it. Your task is daunting you have to ensure that none of the aliens get within firing range of earth. The point of no return is marked with a &lsquo;X&rsquo; on the left of the screen. Once any of the advancing ships pass this point the game is over &minus; you will have lost. Your only hope is to wipe out all the aliens with your missiles. Every missile that hits its target increases your chance of saving the world.</p> <p>This game is especially exciting to play because of the use of a two-tone throbbing sound that decreases in pitch as the invaders get closer. If you play this game on a colour TV you&rsquo;ll see that the ships are red and yellow.</p> <h3>How to play</h3> <p>You can move your missile launcher to left and right using the appropriate arrow keys. Press the up arrow key to fire a missile. You score points for every alien you hit, the ones further away from you accounting for more points than the nearer ones. The game is over when you have destroyed all the invaders or when the nearest remaining ones reach the point marked by the &lsquo;X&rsquo;.</p> </blockquote>
3012DISC133Bomber Command (AKA Bomb Raid)Fontana PublishingB/BomberCommand-3012.ssdBShooter (Gallery)Bomber1984Gwyn Dewey, Tim Hartnell, Ian HuttGiant Book Of Games For Your BBC Micro (BOOK)11NY0<p style="text-align: justify;">Published in the book "The Giant book of games for your BBC micro" from Fontana Publishing, which contains the following description.</p> <blockquote> <p>In this program, based on one by Gwyn Dewey, you are in control of an aeroplane which has to make an emergency landing. Unfortunately, in order to land you must destroy the buildings which are in your way.</p> <p>There are full instructions within the program. Here's the listing so you can throw your weight (and a few bombs) about.</p> </blockquote>
3013DISC133BreakthroughPersonal Software (Argus Specialist Publications Ltd.) (ASP)B/Breakthrough-3013.ssdMBat And BallBreakout, Pong1982Mike James11NY0<p>Published in "Personal Software" magazine issue 1, Summer 1982.</p>
3014DISC133Brick Layer (AKA Bricklayer)Pan Books Ltd., Personal Computer News (PCN) (VNU Publications)B/BrickLayer-3014.ssdBSpace Shooter (Gallery)1983Robert Erskine, Humphrey Walwyn, Paul Stanley, Michael BewsSixty programs for the BBC Micro (BOOK)11NY0<p>Published in the book <em>Sixty Programs for the BBC Micro</em> by <em>Pan Books Ltd</em>, in association with <em>Personal Computer News</em>.</p> <p>The book contains the following description:</p> <blockquote> <p>You are in control of a small aircraft which flies across the top of the screen. From the bottom of the screen, a large wall is being built up which will eventually fill the whole of the playing area. The object of the game is to drop men out of the aircraft, aiming to plummet them through gaps in the wall to the bottom of the screen. If a man should hit any part of the wall then a life will be lost. In order to create gaps for the men to drop through and to prevent the wall advancing too far up the screen, you also have the option of dropping bombs which blow sections of the wall away.</p> </blockquote>
3015DISC133Capture The QuarkGranada Technical Books (Granada Publishing Ltd.)C/CaptureTheQuark-3015.ssdBBoard GameFox And Hounds1983Mike James, S.M. Gee, Kay Ewbank21 games for the BBC Micro (BOOK)11NY0<p>Published in the book <em>21 games for the BBC micro</em> by Mike James, S. M. Gee and Kay Ewbank, published by <em>Granada publishing Ltd</em>.</p> <p>&nbsp;</p> <p>The book contains the following description:</p> <blockquote> <p>What on earth is a &lsquo;quark&rsquo;? Well may you ask that question, but to find out you&rsquo;ll have to play this game. Here are just a few clues. The game is played on an eight-by-eight checkered board and the object of the game is to trap the quark and prevent him from reaching the bottom of the board. To do this you have two, three or four (determined at random) pieces, or &lsquo;quatlins&rsquo;, which can be moved diagonally one square at a time and only up the board. The quark also moves diagonally but he can move both forwards and backwards.</p> <h3>How to play</h3> <p>At the beginning of the game your quatlins (two, three or four of them according to the luck of the draw) are ranged along the bottom line and the quark is at the top of the board. It is your move first. You&rsquo;ll notice that one of your quatlins is displayed in different colours from the rest. This is the piece that is ready to move. If you want to move another piece hit any key and control will pass to the next piece in an anti-clockwise direction. Try pressing keys to see this in operation. When you are ready to move a piece press the left arrow key if you want to move diagonally forward left and the right arrow key if you want to move diagonally forward right. Once you have moved, the quark will make his move automatically and its your turn again. The BBC Micro will display a message when the game is won, either by you or the quark, but if you want to resign before this, type &ldquo;R&rdquo;. Just in case you hit this key by mistake you will be given the chance to reconsider and will have to answer &ldquo;Y&rdquo; or &ldquo;N&rdquo; to the question &ldquo;Resign?&rdquo;.</p> </blockquote>
3016DISC133Ghost LaneFontana PublishingG/GhostLane-3016.ssdBPlatformerFrogger1984Tim Hartnell, Ian HuttGiant Book Of Games For Your BBC Micro (BOOK)11NY0<p>Published in the book "The Giant book of games for your BBC micro" from Fontana Publishing, which contained the following description:</p> <blockquote> <p>In this game, based loosely on the popular arcade game in which you have to get a frog across a busy highway, you have to help a number of ghosts (who have wandered out of yet another popular arcade game) across four lanes of traffic.</p> </blockquote>
3017DISC133Grand PrixComputer & Video Games (C&VG) (EMAP National Publications Ltd.)G/GrandPrix-3017.ssdMDriving (Top Down)1984Mark Witham11NY0<p>Published In the July 1984 issue of Computer &amp; Video Games. Issue 33.</p>
3018DISC133Moon Reskue (AKA Moon Mission)Computer & Video Games (C&VG) (EMAP National Publications Ltd.)M/MoonReskue-3018.ssdMSpaceLunar Rescue1983S. Roberts11NY0<p>Published In the December 1983 issue of Computer &amp; Video Games. Issue 26.</p>
3019DISC133OxygenLaserbugO/Oxygen-3019.ssdMMazeAvoid 'em1982Paul Barbour11NY0<p>Published in issue 05 of Laserbug user group magazine in October 1982.</p>
3020DISC133Pro - Golf (AKA Pro Golf)Century Communications Ltd.P/ProGolf-3020.ssdBSport (Golf)1983Jeff Aughton, Ray DerbyBest Of PCW Software For The BBC Micro (BOOK)11NY0<p>Published on the <a href="index.php?rt_R=&amp;rt_B=&amp;rt_M=&amp;rt_P=&amp;rt_U=&amp;rt_W=&amp;rt_L=&amp;search=best+of+PCW+software&amp;on_T=on&amp;on_Y=on&amp;on_P=on&amp;on_A=on&amp;on_G=on&amp;on_S=on&amp;on_Z=on&amp;on_C=on&amp;sort=a">Best of PCW software for the BBC Micro</a> compilation from Personal Computer World magazine.</p> <p>These compilation cassettes were published by Century Communications Ltd.</p> <p>The book accompanying the Best of PCW software for the BBC Micro contained the following description:</p> <blockquote> <p>This program provides a simulated round of golf. You must use your skill and judgement to decide which club to use in each situation and how hard to hit the ball. Remember to use club 19, your putter, when you are on the green. Other instructions are displayed when the game is run. See you in the clubhouse!</p> </blockquote>
3021DISC133PteragonPopular Computing Weekly (Sunshine Publications Ltd.)P/Pteragon-3021.ssdMShooter (Gallery)1982A.J. Snell11NY0<p>The listing was published in Popular Computing Weekly, Vol. 1, No. 21 (9th September 1982).</p>
3022DISC133Puzzle (AKA Puzzle Program)LaserbugP/Puzzle-3022.ssdMPuzzleSliding Block Puzzle1982Paul Barbour11NY0<p>Published in issue 06 of Laserbug user group magazine in November 1982.</p>
3023DISC133ScribbleNewnes Technical Books (Butterworth And Co. Ltd.)S/Scribble-3023.ssdBWord GamesScrabble1984Derrick DainesBBC Micro programs in BASIC (BOOK)16NY0<p>Published in the book <em>BBC Micro Programs in Basic</em> from <em>Newnes Technical Books</em>, which contains the following description:</p> <blockquote> <p>Scribble is a game for any number of players up to six, and has much in common with Scrabble, Lexicon and similar word games. The object is to make words, for which the computer awards points, the first player reaching a score of 200 points being the winner.</p> <p>On his or her turn, the player may do one of three things: (a) shuffle the letter pool, (b) take a letter from the pool and add it to his hand, or (c) make a word from the letters in his hand. To shuffle the pool, the player simply presses RETURN. To take up a letter from the pool, the letter is typed. The computer removes the letter from the pool and adds it to those in the player's hand, then selects another letter for the pool. To play a word, the player types the whole word and presses RETURN. The computer checks that the word is possible from the letters in the hand, and if so, asks if any other player objects to the word or to its spelling. If all is well, the score is calculated and the letters are removed from the player's hand.</p> <p>Please note very carefully that the score for a word depends upon (a) the individual values of the letters making up the word, (b) the length of the word, with longer words scoring heavily, and (c) the number of letters remaining in the hand; the more letters left unused, the greater the penalty. At the extreme, it is just possible to play a short word, have a lot of letters left over and so be awarded a negative score!</p> <p>There are 'jokers' in the form of '*', which have no value but which may be used in place of any letter. To pick up such a joker, the '*' must be typed. On the other hand, to play a word containing a joker, the player does not include '*', but types the whole word as he or she wishes it to be. The computer first checks for normal letters and if one or more short, checks for jokers.</p> <p>Before and after each player's move there is a timed delay for thought and observation, but players may move the game on swiftly by pressing RETURN. Finally, the number of times that each player may shuffle the letter pool is limited, dependent upon the number of players.</p> </blockquote>
3024DISC133Sea SubFontana PublishingS/SeaSub-3024.ssdBShooter (Gallery)Submarines1984Tim Hartnell, Ian HuttGiant Book Of Games For Your BBC Micro (BOOK)11NY0<p>Published in the book <em>Giant Book of Games</em> from <em>Fontana Publishing</em></p> <p>The book contains the following description:</p> <blockquote> <p>You are the submarine at the bottom of the screen in the game, and your task is to destroy all the ships as they sail overhead. You are fighting against the clock all through the game, and have only one minute to accomplish your mission.</p> <p>You move your sub left and right with the CAPS LOCK and CTRL keys, and fire using the RETURN key. The smaller the ship, the faster it travels, and the points you score are related to the size of the ship and how far away from you it is. You can only fire one torpedo at a time.</p> </blockquote>
3025DISC133SlideNewnes Technical Books (Butterworth And Co. Ltd.)S/Slide-3025.ssdBPuzzleSliding Block Puzzle1984Derrick DainesBBC Micro programs in BASIC (BOOK)11NY0<p>Published in the book "BBC micro programs in BASIC" from Newnes technical books.</p> <p>The book contains the following description:</p> <blockquote> <p>This program is a computer implementation of those little plastic puzzles that you can buy, in which the user slides the pieces one at a time into the only available space. The object of the exercise is to arrange them in their natural order:</p> <table> <tbody> <tr> <td>&nbsp;A&nbsp;</td> <td>&nbsp;B&nbsp;</td> <td>&nbsp;C&nbsp;</td> <td>&nbsp;D&nbsp;</td> </tr> <tr> <td>&nbsp;E&nbsp;</td> <td>&nbsp;F&nbsp;</td> <td>&nbsp;G&nbsp;</td> <td>&nbsp;H&nbsp;</td> </tr> <tr> <td>&nbsp;I&nbsp;</td> <td>&nbsp;J&nbsp;</td> <td>&nbsp;K&nbsp;</td> <td>&nbsp;L&nbsp;</td> </tr> <tr> <td>&nbsp;M&nbsp;</td> <td>&nbsp;N&nbsp;</td> <td>&nbsp;O&nbsp;</td> <td>&nbsp;</td> </tr> </tbody> </table> <p>&nbsp;</p> <p>The advantage of this implementation over the plastic type is that every start condition is totally random and it is amazingly fast. Also, as a special dispensation, but only once per game, the user may swap any two letters, which is useful of course if you get into a situation you cannot see your way out of. Finally, the computer counts your moves and gives you a grading when - or if - you complete the puzzle.</p> </blockquote>
3026DISC133Space TrafficPan Books Ltd., Personal Computer News (PCN) (VNU Publications)S/SpaceTraffic-3026.ssdBAvoid 'emSpace1983Paul StanleySixty programs for the BBC Micro (BOOK)11NY0<p>Published in the book <em>Sixty Programs for the BBC Micro</em> by <em>Pan Books Ltd</em>, in association with <em>Personal Computer News</em>.</p> <p>The book contains the following description:</p> <blockquote> <p>As you travel about in the midst of an asteroid belt recovering lost satellites (well, someone has to do it), you are assailed by missiles and enemy spacecraft which you can either dodge or attack. Movement is either to left or right using the Z and X keys and your cannon can be fired with the M key, although this will lose you points.</p> <p>The satellites are collected by manoeuvering your spaceship into them and points are gained for each one which you manage to recover. Collision with other objects results in destruction, although you are allocated five lives at the start of each game.</p> </blockquote>
3027DISC133Sprint 1Self-publishedS/Sprint1-3027.ssdPDriving (Top Down)Sprint2018Richard BroadhurstR11NY0<p>This is an emulator of the 1978 game "Sprint 1" from Kee Games. More info <a href="https://stardot.org.uk/forums/viewtopic.php?f=57&amp;t=16238&amp;p=223543&amp;hilit=sprint#p223543">here</a></p> <p>It cannot be played online. It must be played on a real BBC Micro with an analogue joystick.</p>
3028DISC134Asteroid DodgePopular Computing Weekly (Sunshine Publications Ltd.)A/AsteroidDodge-3028.ssdMAvoid 'emSpace1983Phillip Wells11NY0<p>The listing was published in Popular Computing Weekly, Vol. 2, No. 40 (6th October 1983).</p>
3029DISC134Derby DayGranada Technical Books (Granada Publishing Ltd.)D/DerbyDay-3029.ssdBSport (Horse Racing)Gambling1983Mike James, S.M. Gee, Kay Ewbank21 games for the BBC Micro (BOOK)11NY0<p>Published in the book <em>21 games for the BBC micro</em> by Mike James, S. M. Gee and Kay Ewbank, published by <em>Granada publishing Ltd</em>.</p> <p>&nbsp;</p> <p>The book contains the following description:</p> <blockquote> <p>This is a very simple betting game with an impressive and convincing horse race display plus an appropriate musical accompaniment. The tune is &lsquo;Camptown Races&rsquo; and if you&rsquo;ve ever heard it before, you&rsquo;re sure to recognise it. If you want to show off the graphics and sound capabilities of your BBC Micro this program provides a good demonstration.</p> <h3>How to play</h3> <p>At the beginning of the game you are allocated a hundred chips. You have to bet on which horse will come in first and must decide how much to stake (the odds are five to one, so if you win having placed 20 you will receive 100). The BBC Micro keeps a tally of your winnings and losses and will tell you if you go broke. During the race, the horse you have backed stands out from the rest of the field &minus; it is the white one. The race is run automatically and so there&rsquo;s nothing you can do to make your horse win except cheer it along.</p> </blockquote>
3030DISC134DropoutFontana PublishingD/Dropout-3030.ssdBSpace Shooter (Gallery)Kamikaze1984Tim Hartnell, Ian Hutt, Paul TolandGiant Book Of Games For Your BBC Micro (BOOK)11NY0<p>Published in the book "The Giant book of games for your BBC micro" from Fontana Publishing.</p> <p>The book contains the following description:</p> <blockquote> <p>Full instructions for this dynamic game, based on an idea by Paul Toland, are included in the program. Aliens are stacked above you, ready to fall when their stack is full. You can shoot an alien at any time, but the lower they are when hit, the more points they are worth.</p> <p>The difficulty level determines the speed with which the aliens appear above you. The program includes a high-score feature.<u></u></p> </blockquote>

The geese are back from the north and the freezer is empty. Don't worry about the corpses - your faithful hound will deal with those after the game is over. Just blast away with your shooter and notch up a handsome tally.</p> </blockquote>

3034DISC134Light CyclesFontana PublishingL/LightCycles-3034.ssdBMazeTron, Light Cycles1984Neal Cavalier-SmithGiant Book Of Games For Your BBC Micro (BOOK)11NY0<p>Published in the book "The Giant book of games for your BBC micro" from Fontana Publishing.</p> <p>The book contained the following description:</p> <blockquote> <p>In this fast-moving game you have to ride your light cycle around the screen avoiding the computer's cycle and making sure you don't run over the trail left by either your own bike or the computer's. The aim of the game is to enclose the computer so that it cannot move. It, of course, is trying to do the same thing to you.</p> <p>You control your cycle as follows:</p> <ul> <li>: To move up.</li> <li>/ To move down.</li> <li>Z To move left.</li> <li>X To move right.</li> </ul> <p>If you hold down the SHIFT key, your cycle will move twice as fast, which gives you the chance of riding through trails. However, this option should not be tried lightly because it is programmed to work only around 50 per cent of the time.</p> <p>Light Cycles was written by Neal Cavalier-Smith.</p> </blockquote> <p>&nbsp;</p> <p>&nbsp;</p>

You use the 'X' and 'Z' keys to move yourself right and left. At the end of the game (when you hit an asteroid) you'll be told the number of 'light years' you have managed to traverse.</p> </blockquote>
3036DISC134Minelay (AKA Mine Lay)Pan Books Ltd., Personal Computer News (PCN) (VNU Publications)M/Minelay-3036.ssdBMaze1983Paul StanleySixty programs for the BBC Micro (BOOK)11NY0<p>Published in the book "Sixty Programs for the BBC Micro" by Pan Books Ltd. In association with Personal Computer News.</p> <p>The book contains the following description:</p> <blockquote> <p>Minelay is a maze game in which your hero runs about collecting 5 eggs and avoiding the deadly mines which are scattered randomly about the maze. A fiendish little 'minelayer' scuttles around the screen in hot pursuit. Contact with this persistent creature results in instant death. Here is the good news. A number of axes are dotted around the playing area which the player can pick up and carry around. Each axe can be used both to break through maze walls and also to fend off direct attacks by the minelayer.</p> </blockquote>
3037DISC134Mutant Rats (AKA Giant Rats)Pan Books Ltd., Personal Computer News (PCN) (VNU Publications)M/MutantRats-3037.ssdBMaze1983Ian Thomas, Paul StanleySixty programs for the BBC Micro (BOOK)11YY0<p>Original program by Paul Stanley, converted for the BBC Micro by Ian Thomas.</p> <p>Published in the book "Sixty Programs for the BBC Micro" by Pan Books Ltd. In association with Personal Computer News.</p> <p>The book contains the following description:</p> <blockquote> <p>The object of Giant Rats is to direct a man through a maze to reach the girl, whilst being pursued by a killer rat. You have a displayed time limit in which to move before the girl mutates - and if you are unlucky she will unpredictably change places with the rat! If the rat should reach the girl first, she will disappear altogether. At the beginning of the game you are shown the positions of up to four randomly placed mines which you must try to memorise since they will remain invisible for the remainder of the game.</p> </blockquote>
3038DISC134One Armed BanditLaserbugO/OneArmedBandit-3038.ssdMSimulation (Fruit Machine)Gambling1983Paul Barbour11NY0<p>Published in issue 12 of Laserbug user group magazine in May 1983.</p>
3039DISC134Pot ShotGranada Technical Books (Granada Publishing Ltd.)P/PotShot-3039.ssdBShooter (Gallery)1983Mike James, S.M. Gee, Kay Ewbank21 games for the BBC Micro (BOOK)11NY0<p>Published in the book <em>21 games for the BBC micro</em> by Mike James, S. M. Gee and Kay Ewbank, published by <em>Granada publishing Ltd</em>.</p> <p>&nbsp;</p> <p>The book contains the following description:</p> <blockquote> <p>This game provides the ideal type of target practice. However many times you score a direct hit, the magic bird continues to fly on, allowing you to take aim and fire again and again. The elements of this game are simple &minus; a blue sky with a single white cloud, a bird winging its way from left to right and your rifle sight. The object is straightforward &minus; to line up the sight with the bird and shoot it &minus; but in practice its not that simple. Every time you fire, your rifle &lsquo;kicks&rsquo; to one side or the other so you have to re-align your sight for your next shot and the bird (and your sight too) disappears behind the cloud when they reach it. A total of five birds fly across the sky and there is no limit to the number of hits you can score &minus; your total for each bird and the whole game are displayed at the end. There is a convincing sound every time you fire your rifle and a distinctive bell-like sound when you hit the bird.</p> <h3>How to play</h3> <p>To hit the target you have to line the cross point of your sight up with the centre of the bird. Use all four arrow keys to move your sight and press &lsquo;F&rsquo; to fire. There are five birds in all and you may hit each one as often as you can.</p> </blockquote>
3040DISC134SimonComputer & Video Games (C&VG) (EMAP National Publications Ltd.)S/Simon-3040.ssdMMemory GameTraditional Games, Simon1984Jonathan O'Donnell11NY0<p>Published In the February 1984 issue of Computer &amp; Video Games. Issue 28 in the 'Book of games' supplement.</p>

3042DISC134ZombiesCentury Communications Ltd.Z/Zombies-3042.ssdBMazeZombies1983Daniel Lucas, P. BarkerBest Of PCW Software For The BBC Micro (BOOK)11NY0<p>The original program was by P. Barker,&nbsp; and was converted for the BBC Micro by Daniel Lucas.</p> <p>Published on the <a href="index.php?rt_R=&amp;rt_B=&amp;rt_M=&amp;rt_P=&amp;rt_U=&amp;rt_W=&amp;rt_L=&amp;search=best+of+PCW+software&amp;on_T=on&amp;on_Y=on&amp;on_P=on&amp;on_A=on&amp;on_G=on&amp;on_S=on&amp;on_Z=on&amp;on_C=on&amp;sort=a">Best of PCW software for the BBC Micro</a> compilation from Personal Computer World magazine.</p> <p>These compilation cassettes were published by Century Communications Ltd.</p> <p>The book accompanying the Best of PCW software for the BBC Micro contained the following description:</p> <blockquote> <p>In this game you are trapped in a graveyard at midnight, and all the Zombies are crawling out of their graves to try and catch you! 3043DISC135Rainbow SquashGranada Technical Books (Granada Publishing Ltd.)R/RainbowSquash-3043.ssdBBat And BallPong1983Mike James, S.M. Gee, Kay Ewbank21 games for the BBC Micro (BOOK)11NY0<p>Published in the book <em>21 games for the BBC micro</em> by Mike James, S. M. Gee and Kay Ewbank, published by <em>Granada publishing Ltd</em>.</p> <p>&nbsp;</p> <p>The book contains the following description:</p> <blockquote> <p>This is a colourful version of the popular computer squash game which is also enhanced by the addition of sound &minus; a cheery beep every time the ball bounces either on the sides of the court or against the bat, and a dismal tone every time a ball goes out of play. Its other feature is that as you improve in skill the game gets more difficult and if you then start to get worse it gets easier. This means that your BBC Micro will always give you a challenge that is suited to your ability &minus; which makes it the perfect partner.</p> <h3>How to play</h3> <p>At the start of the game the bat is at the bottom of the screen and in the centre. You control the left and right movement of the bat by pressing the appropriate arrow keys. Every time you make two hits in succession the position of the bat changes &minus; it moves nearer to the top of the screen &minus; which makes returning the ball more difficult. If you then miss a shot the ball will move back one position, making it easier. You score a point for every hit and you will be served a total of 10 balls. Information about the number of balls played and hits scored is displayed on the screen continuously.</p> </blockquote>
3044DISC134Fox & Hounds (AKA Fox And Hounds)Personal Software (Argus Specialist Publications Ltd.) The faster you go, the more your score increases.</p> <p>The game ends when your car skids off the track and mounts the grass. Obviously, at higher speeds the car tends to skid more when turning. If you go too fast, you'll lose control. The car starts off at around ten miles an hour.</p> </blockquote>

3052DISC135Ski RunFontana PublishingS/SkiRun-3052.ssdBSport (Skiing)1984Tim Hartnell, Ian HuttGiant Book Of Games For Your BBC Micro (BOOK)11NY0<p>Published in the book "The Giant book of games for your BBC micro" from Fontana Publishing.</p> <p>The book contains the following description:</p> <blockquote> <p>In this program you have to steer your skier down the ski-slope, dodging the trees as you go. Your speed increases as you progress down the slope. If you move off the side, you'll see yourself reappear on the other side of the screen. If you drop off the bottom of the world, you'll reappear on the top of the screen. The 'Z' keys moves you left, and the '/' moves you right. The skier automatically moves down unless he is moving across the slope. The time for the completed run will be shown at the end of the game.</p> </blockquote>
3053DISC135TanxPan Books Ltd., Personal Computer News (PCN) (VNU Publications)T/Tanx-3053.ssdBShooterTrajectory, Worms1983Robert Erskine, Humphrey Walwyn, Paul Stanley, Michael BewsSixty programs for the BBC Micro (BOOK)22NY0<p>Published in the book <em>Sixty Programs for the BBC Micro</em> by <em>Pan Books Ltd</em>, in association with <em>Personal Computer News</em>.</p> <p>The book contains the following description</p> <blockquote> <p>Tanx is a two player game in which two guns are placed on either side of a range of randomly generated hills. Each player takes turns in attempting to hit the gun on the other side by entering the angle and velocity of fire. The winner is the player with the highest score after a total of seven hits have been made. Your best chance of success is to use the smallest possible angle of elevation for a given velocity and, at higher speeds, it may be possible to fire through one of the hills.</p> </blockquote> <p>&nbsp;</p>

3055DISC135Beasty BugsMicro User, The (later Acorn Computing) (Database Publications)B/BeastyBugs-3055.ssdMBoard Game1989Patrick Whittaker11NY0<p>Published in Micro User Magazine vol.6 issue 11 in January 1989</p>
3056DISC135Solitaire MazeFontana PublishingS/SolitaireMaze-3056.ssdBPuzzle1984Mike O'Neill, Ian HuttGiant Book Of Games For Your BBC Micro (BOOK)11NY0<p>Published in the book "The Giant book of games for your BBC micro" from Fontana Publishing, which contains the following description:</p> <blockquote> <p>Here's a game for the very patient and skilled. Written initially by Mike O'Neill and modified by Ian Hutt, Solitaire Maze challenges you to a game of strategy.</p> <p>You control between one and five circular pieces. There is an equal number of diamond-shaped pieces which do not move during the game. The object of the exercise is to move your pieces around the maze so that ultimately each one covers a different diamond.</p> <p>A timer runs while the program is underway. This tells you how long it took to complete the latest game, and the fastest time so far.</p> </blockquote>
3057DISC135Moon LanderPan Books Ltd., Personal Computer News (PCN) (VNU Publications)M/MoonLander-3057.ssdB1983Robert Erskine, Colin TannerSixty programs for the BBC Micro (BOOK)11NY0<p>Originally written for the Sinclair Spectrum by Robert Erskine, and converted for the BBC Micro by Colin Tanner.</p> <p>Published in the book <em>Sixty Programs for the BBC Micro</em> by <em>Pan Books Ltd</em>, in association with <em>Personal Computer News</em>. The book contains the following description:</p> <blockquote> <p>This is an up-market real-time lander program which gives you an opportunity to grapple with the problems which face a space-lagged cruiser commander returning home after a long haul. The object of the exercise is to land your craft on the chillingly small landing-pad at the bottom of the screen. Precision is the name of the game, because if your rate of descent is greater than -5 you and your crew are gonners. A word of warning: if you over-fire your rockets you'll disappear into hyperspace until returning back on screen, plummeting to your doom unless you've been doing some nifty blind flying to slow your descent.</p> </blockquote>
3058DISC135Derby Day (AKA Derby)Newnes Technical Books (Butterworth And Co. Ltd.)D/DerbyDay-3058.ssdBSport (Horse Racing)Gambling1984Derrick DainesBBC Micro programs in BASIC (BOOK)16NY0<p>Published in the book "BBC micro programs in BASIC" from Newnes technical books. The book contains the following description:</p> <blockquote> <p>Another old favourite, especially when a group of friends congregate and shout themselves hoarse cheering on their fancied nag. Up to six can play, each starting with &pound;100. The 'meet' starts a 2.00 pm and goes on until 6.00 pm, with a race every 15 minutes' game time, stopping sooner if any player runs out of cash. There is a pool of 20 horses, each with its own handicap. Only six horses are randomly selected out of the pool, so the possible permutations of horses running against each other are enormous. In addition, after every race the winning horse has its handicap increased - as per Jockey Club rules - while the others have theirs reduced. Similarly, Honest Joe the bookie will shorten the odds on winning horses and lengthen them on losers. The result is that it is a good test of judgement and skill at picking winners.</p> <p>The first screen gives the title and asks for the number of players. The second screen seeks each player's name and then we move into the game loop, which consists of three more screens. The first is the Honest Joe. We are given the number of six horses, their names and odds, each player in turn is asked for his or her bet - the number of the horse backed and the amount.</p> <p>The next screen is the race proper, and comprises four broad bands of green representing sections of the course. For verisimilitude we add posts and rails, a winning post and the start line, behind which we see the six horses and riders. On pressing RETURN, the names disappear and six horses race forward. As they reach the right edge of one section, they appear at the left edge of the one above, continuing in this way until one reaches the finish. The name of the winning horse is thrown on the screen and the action is frozen while players argue, if they feel like it - although it won't do them any good!</p> <p>The final screen addresses each player by name and gives news of what happened to their bet and their current cash state. If all have cash the game time is advanced and we return to Honest Joe Bloggs to place bets for the next race.</p> </blockquote>
3059DISC135PokerComputing Today (Argus Specialist Publications Ltd.) (ASP)P/Poker-3059.ssdMCard GameCard Game (Poker), Gambling1984P.J. Kenworthy11NY0<p>The game listing was published in the March 1984 issue of Personal Computing Today. Vol.6, No.1.</p> <p>**Please note: the listing may have problems and may not play accurate Poker in all situations** If anyone has the April 1984 issue of Computing Today, please contact us.&nbsp;</p>
3060DISC135Laser AttackGranada Technical Books (Granada Publishing Ltd.)L/LaserAttack-3060.ssdBSpace Shooter (Gallery)1983Mike James, S.M. Gee, Kay Ewbank21 games for the BBC Micro (BOOK)11NY0<p>Published in the book <em>21 games for the BBC micro</em> by Mike James, S. M. Gee and Kay Ewbank, published by <em>Granada publishing Ltd</em>.</p> <p>&nbsp;</p> <p>The book contains the following description:</p> <blockquote> <p>This is a very exciting and fast moving space fight game that uses sound effects and some rather unusual graphics techniques to good effect. The screen is treated as if it were a spherical universe. So, if you go off the top of the screen you re-appear at the bottom, and if you go off at the right, you re-appear at the left. This game is a race against the clock. You have a hundred seconds in which to annihilate the enemy ship with your infallible laser weapon &minus; the chase is on.</p> <h3>How to play</h3> <p>At the beginning of this game you have to select a difficulty factor. This governs the unpredictability of the enemy ship&rsquo;s course and the number of stars that appear. The stars act as obstacles in this game. If you hit one you will be deflected at random so the fewer there are the easier it is to steer your course. Your ship moves continuously and is shaped like an arrowhead and can point in any of eight directions. Every time you press any key it turns clockwise through 45 degrees. The enemy is a revolving cartwheel-shaped disc that meanders through space. To fire your laser press the &lsquo;up arrow&rsquo; key. Your weapon will fire in a straight line from the point of your arrow. If you hit the enemy ship it will disintegrate with appropriate sound and visual effects. The time taken is constantly displayed at the top left of the screen and when it reaches 100 your time is up.</p> </blockquote>
3061DISC135ReversiComputer & Video Games (C&VG) (EMAP National Publications Ltd.)R/Reversi-3061.ssdMBoard GameBoard Game (Reversi)1984David Waterfield11NY0<p>Published In the February 1984 issue of Computer &amp; Video Games. Issue 28</p>
3062DISC999TheSchool Of Death (AKA School Of Death)Games Computing (Argus Specialist Publications Ltd.) (ASP)S/SchoolOfDeath-3062.ssdMAdventureText, Text Adventure1984Steve W. Lucas (S.W. Lucas)11NYY<p>Published in Games Computing magazine, issue 1, January 1984.</p> <p>The listing was for the ORIC-1 but was in a standard BASIC, so has been ported to the BBC Micro in 2019.</p>
3063DISC136SnakeGranada Technical Books (Granada Publishing Ltd.)S/Snake-3063.ssdBMazeSnake1984Mike James, S.M. Gee, Kay EwbankElectron Gamesmaster (BOOK)11YesNY0<p>Published in the book "The Electron Gamesmaster" from Granada Technical Books (Granada Publishing Ltd.). See the book for a lengthy explanation of the program, which includes the following:</p> <blockquote> <p>Even this simple game involving a snake is quite addictive! This is not to say that there&rsquo;s no scope both for improvement and innovation, but overall the game is a great success and has a speed and interest normally only found in assembly language games.</p> </blockquote>
3064DISC136Pac-Track (AKA Pac-Trac)Virgin BooksP/PacTrack-3064.ssdBMazeSnake1983Alex GollnerGames For Your BBC Micro (BOOK)11NY0<p>Published in the book <em>Games For Your BBC Micro</em> by <em>Virgin Books</em> Ltd. It contains the following description:</p> <blockquote> <p>In this game your maze-man is off on another adventure. His aim is to eat up all the blocks but he is in some difficulty because, as he moves around, he leaves a trail of blocks he cannot digest and he cannot therefore retrace his path. You have 90 seconds to eat up all the blocks.</p> </blockquote>
3065DISC136Solo DogfightPan Books Ltd., Personal Computer News (PCN) (VNU Publications)S/SoloDogfight-3065.ssdBShooterDog Fight1983Robert Erskine, Ian ThomasSixty programs for the BBC Micro (BOOK)11NY0<p>Published in the book "Sixty Programs for the BBC Micro" by Pan Books Ltd. In association with Personal Computer News.</p> <p>The book notes that this program was originally by Robert Erskine and converted for the BBC Micro by Ian Thomas. It contains the following description:</p> <blockquote> <p>Up in the wild blue yonder, you and the enemy ace are duelling above the trenches. Swoop down on the foe, hang on his tail, catch him unawares from below, with your trusty Brownings spitting leaden death. All good clean fun, but watch for the wraparound!</p> </blockquote>

3070DISC136Sharp ShooterFontana PublishingS/SharpShooter-3070.ssdBShooterBoot Hill1984Ant Hurrion, Tim Hartnell, Ian HuttGiant Book Of Games For Your BBC Micro (BOOK)11NY0<p>Published in the book "The Giant book of games for your BBC micro" from Fontana Publishing, which contains the following description:</p> <blockquote> <p>In this fun program, based on an idea from Ant Hurrion, you control the man on the right of the cacti on your screen. You must shoot it out with the computer gunman.</p> <p>The winner is the marksman who first gains 100 points. There are several levels of difficulty, and you're able to choose the level at which you'll start play at the start of the game.</p> </blockquote>
3071DISC136FroglingGranada Technical Books (Granada Publishing Ltd.)F/Frogling-3071.ssdBPlatformerFrogger1984Mike James, S.M. Gee, Kay EwbankElectron Gamesmaster (BOOK)11YesNY0<p>Published in the book "The Electron Gamesmaster" from Granada Technical Books (Granada Publishing Ltd.).&nbsp; The book contains the following description:</p> <blockquote> <p>A frog plays a central role in this as well as in last chapter&rsquo;s game. Frogling is a version of the classic arcade game of Frogger. The object of the game is to get a frog safely across a busy road, dodging oncoming traffic, and then across a fast flowing river, by jumping on floating logs The implementation of this game in BASIC provides an opportunity to explain and experiment with a type of animation that relies on scrolling.</p> </blockquote>
3072DISC999TheTombs Of ArkenstoneArnold-Wheaton SoftwareT/TombsOfArkenstone-3072.ssdWAdventureRPG, Text, Educational, Text Adventure1984Bob Hart11NY0<p>An educational adventure/RPG used in schools.</p>
3073DISC999Dungeon Of DoomUsborne Publishing Ltd.D/DungeonOfDoom-3073.ssdBRPGAdventure1984Les Howarth, Cheryl Evans, Chris OxladeSTD11NY0<p>Dungeon Of Doom&nbsp;can be found as a type-in listing in the book Write Your Own Fantasy Games For Your Microcomputer, a free PDF of which is available to download from&nbsp;<a href="https://usborne.com/browse-books/features/computer-and-coding-books/">Usborne Publishing</a>.</p> <p>A big thank-you to&nbsp;<a href="https://github.com/bchiha/dungeon-of-doom">Brian</a>, who typed in and improved the listing, uploaded instructions for playing the game, and designed the character and dungeon levels.</p>

3075DISC136Spider And FlyVirgin BooksS/SpiderAndFly-3075.ssdBCollect 'Em Up1983Alex GollnerGames For Your BBC Micro (BOOK)11NY0<p>Published in the book <em>Games For Your BBC Micro</em> by <em>Virgin Books</em> Ltd. It contains the following description:</p> <blockquote> <p>You are a very hungry spider, hanging from a thread on the left-hand side of the screen, whose main aim in life is to get your lunch. When six rather fat flies come into view, you have 99 seconds to munch your way through as many of them as you can. Use the &lsquo;&lsquo;Y&rsquo;&rsquo; key to go up and the &lsquo;&lsquo;B&rsquo;&rsquo; key to go down.</p> </blockquote>
3076DISC136Master Code (AKA Mastercode)Clemoes SoftwareM/MasterCode-3076.ssdRPuzzleMastermind1983M. ClemoesGames Of Deduction11NY0<p>Published on the 3 game compilation "Games Of Deduction". The games included were "3D Maze", "Colour Cube", and "Master Code".</p>
3077DISC136Saucer EncounterFontana PublishingS/SaucerEncounter-3077.ssdBSpaceLunar Lander1984Tim Hartnell, Ian Hutt, Garry WilsonGiant Book Of Games For Your BBC Micro (BOOK)11NY0<p>Published in the book "The Giant book of games for your BBC micro" from Fontana Publishing, which contains the following description:</p> <blockquote> <p>In this challenging game, based on an idea by Garry Wilson, you are working in real time, trying to land your spacecraft on the flying saucer which moves across the bottom of the screen.</p> <p>When the game is underway, the screen is dotted with randomly plotted stars, and there's even a right bracket for a moon. Fuel is being consumed all the time, and you must land on the saucer before all the fuel has been used up. Your ' pilot rating' depends, in part, on how little fuel you used up to land successfully. Crash landings do not acquire a rating.</p> </blockquote>
3078DISC136Field-GunYour Computer (IPC Electrical-Electronic Press Ltd.)F/FieldGun-3078.ssdMShooter (Strategy)Trajectory, Worms1983B. Pearce22YY0<p>Published in Your Computer Magazine volume 3 issue 1 in January 1983.</p>
3079DISC136Nine Hole GolfGranada Technical Books (Granada Publishing Ltd.)N/NineHoleGolf-3079.ssdBSport (Golf)1983Mike James, S.M. Gee, Kay Ewbank21 games for the BBC Micro (BOOK)11NY0<p>Published in the book <em>21 games for the BBC micro</em> by Mike James, S. M. Gee and Kay Ewbank, published by <em>Granada publishing Ltd</em>.</p> <p>&nbsp;</p> <p>The book contains the following description:</p> <blockquote> <p>This is a colour graphics game that combines both driving and putting and even includes the hazard of bunkers. You play around a nine hole course with two stages at each hole &minus; the fairway and the green. When you RUN it notice how, in the first stage, the golfer makes his swing and how the ball flies through the air.</p> <p><strong>How to play</strong></p> <p>At the start of each hole you are told the distance to the hole marked on the screen by a flag and asked to select which club you wish to use. If you&rsquo;ve ever played golf, or watched it on TV, you&rsquo;ll know that the lower the number of the club the further it will drive the ball. In other words, select the 1 iron to drive a long way and 8 iron for the really close shots. If you overshoot the green you&rsquo;ll get a new go at the hole and if you drive the ball off the screen you forfeit the hole and move on to the next one. Otherwise, once you get close enough to the hole you&rsquo;ll find yourself on the green. A message will tell you how far you have to putt to the hole and will ask you to select the appropriate club. If you overshoot while putting you will find yourself still at some distance from the hole and will have to carry on putting until your ball drops in to the hole. Your score for each hole is displayed at the end of each hole and a score card for all nine holes is displayed at the end of<br />each round.</p> </blockquote>
3080DISC136Bouncing BugUsborne Publishing Ltd.B/BouncingBug-3080.ssdBMazeSnake1983Les Howarth, Judy TatchellUnderstanding Computer Graphics (BOOK)11NY0<p><em>Bouncing Bug</em> may be found as a type-in listing in <em>Understanding Computer Graphics</em>, a free PDF of this book is available for download from <a href="https://usborne.com/browse-books/features/computer-and-coding-books/">Usborne Publishing</a> (scroll to near the bottom of the page).</p>
3081DISC136WoodwormFontana PublishingW/Woodworm-3081.ssdBMaze1984J. Bull, Tim Hartnell, Ian HuttGiant Book Of Games For Your BBC Micro (BOOK)11NY0<p>Published in the book "The Giant book of games for your BBC micro" from Fontana Publishing, which contains the following description:</p> <blockquote> <p>Picture yourself as a woodworm. If you look like me, that is not hard to do. All you have to do is eat your way across the screen. For the purposes of this game, you must think of the screen as a large chunk of wood. The wood is made up of three types of timber: hard, medium strength and soft. The three types are shown by different colours on the screen: red for the hardest wood, yellow for the medium grade and green for the soft.</p> <p>You must cross the screen in the shortest time possible. Bear in mind that eating through tough wood is more time-consuming and tiring than munching on the softer stuff. Woodworm is based on a program by J. Bull. Full instructions are within the program.</p> </blockquote>

Gee and Kay Ewbank, published by <em>Granada publishing Ltd</em>.</p>
3107DISC138PelmanismYour Computer (IPC Electrical-Electronic Press Ltd.)P/Pelmanism-3107.ssdMCard GamePairs, Pelmanism1983Woodward, Berry22NY0<p>Published in Your Computer Magazine volume 3 issue 5 in May 1983.</p> <p>The article was written by "Woodward and Berry", with no first names given.</p>
3108DISC138PostmanPan Books Ltd., Personal Computer News (PCN) (VNU Publications)P/Postman-3108.ssdBMazeAvoid 'em1983Paul Stanley, Ian Thomas, GrahamSixty programs for the BBC Micro (BOOK)11NY0<p>The program was originally written by Paul Stanley and converted for the BBC Micro by "Graham/Thomas".</p> <p>N.B. "Thomas" will be Ian Thomas, Graham will be a surname, although no first name is known.</p> <p>Published in the book <em>Sixty Programs for the BBC Micro</em> by <em>Pan Books Ltd</em>, in association with <em>Personal Computer News</em>.</p>
3109DISC138Rubik's CubeMicro PressR/RubiksCube-3109.ssdBPuzzleSimulation (Rubik's Cube)1983Robert BrowningQuality Programs For The BBC Micro (BOOK)11NY0<p>The listing for this game was published in the book 'Quality Programs For The BBC Micro' from Micro Press.</p>
3110DISC138Space WarPopular Computing Weekly (Sunshine Publications Ltd.)S/SpaceWar-3110.ssdMStrategy (Spaceship Management)Star Trek1986Mark Ward11NY0<p>Published over three issues of Popular Computing Weekly magazine: volume 5, issues 32, 33, and 34 (August the 7th, 14th and 21st 1986).</p>
